Text:
Chief Complaint:
UC
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 56-year-old F who presents for a follow-up visit for GERD, C. diff colitis, and UC. Patient was seen in 3/2021 by Dr. Swan. On her visit in 5/2022 she reported irregular bowel movements and mucoid stools. She was previously on Miralax and Movantik for constipation prior to her insurance change. Her reflux was well controlled on Omeprazole. On her visit on 9/2022 she reported completing her C. diff therapy with improved diarrhea. On her visit on 1/2023 she was pending approval for Dificid with stable diarrhea symptoms. On her visit on 8/2023 she began having worsening symptoms in 5/2023 with seepage, mucoid stools and intermittent rectal bleeding. CSP was recommended as noted below. On her visit on 10/2023 she was taking Mesalamine and Supp. along with Pred. 40mg with some improvement. She was induced on Entyvio 12/2023. On her visit in 1/2024 she reported some improvement on Entyvio. On her visit in 4/2024 she was doing well with ongoing rectal bleeding and mucoid stools. She had been on Enytvio SQ every 2 weeks. CSP was recommended as noted below.  On her visit in 7/2024 she reported some improvement in bleeding and mucoid drainage and steroids. She continued to have intermittent diarrhea. On her visit in 8/2024 the patient continued to complain of LLQ abdominal pain. She received Skyrizi induction dose in 8/2024. On her visit in 10/24 the patient reported improvement in symptoms. She was last seen on 6/6/2025 and reported doing well overall since her last visit. She had been on Skyrizi injection every 8 weeks with significant clinical improvement. She has 1-2 BMs/day without rectal bleeding or mucoid stools. CSP was recommended as noted below.
Currently she reports that she is feeling well. She went to a football game and did not have any issues. She is on Skyrizi every 8 weeks. She currently has 1 BM every 1-2 days. Denies nocturnal bowel movements or hematochezia. She is also taking pain meds for back pain, oxymorphone and has been experiencing more constipation. She added Miralax and fiber supplements. She also started Ozempic in June 2025 and has not had any GI symptoms. She denies nausea, vomiting, fever, chills, or melena.
_________________________________
Available records reviewed and include the following:
EGD/CSP: 3/2022
EGD: Normal esophagus with regular Z-line. 4 cm sliding hiatal hernia. Nonobstructive peptic ring in the distal esophagus. Multiple benign-appearing gastric polyps, resected with cold snare polypectomy to obtain representative sample. Otherwise normal stomach. Normal duodenum. Path: Fundic gland polyps.
CSP: No evidence of polyps or masses on the surveillance exam. Cecal mucosal friability with colonic erosions, biopsied to evaluate for chronic colitis however this may be related to NSAID use. Mild rectal mucosal friability, biopsied. Path: Single biopsy showing focal active colitis, rectal biopsies were normal.
Labs: 7/2022 Celiac serology negative, Fecal calp >8000, GI PCR positive for C. diff x 2 (7/14/22 and 8/24/22)
Labs: 12/7/2022 C. diff and E. Coli positive.
Labs: 6/2023 GI PCR and C. diff cyto. assay negative.
Labs: 8/2023 GI PCR negative, Fecal calp. 433.
CSP: 9/2023 Path: Focal chronic active colitis, mild activity noted in the right colon, the left colon, and the rectum. Findings are consistent with ulcerative colitis.
Labs: 4/2024 Fecal calp. 3220.
Labs: 5/2024 CDI negative.
CSP: 6/2024 Path: Patchy chronic active proctitis, mild with ulceration.
Labs: 6/2024 Vedo level 34, Anti-Vedo Abs negative.
Labs: 7/2024 CBC and CMP normal
Labs: 10/2024 CRP 8.0
Fecal Calp: 6/2025: 41
Labs: 6/2025: AST/ALT normal. CBC normal. Vit D 38 CRP 3.3 TB neg HBcAb neg HBsAg neg
CSP: 6/2025: No histologic abnormality or dysplasia. Two 4-5mm TA in AC.

Perianal irritation
Assessment:
1. UC: The pathophysiology, diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis of this disorder was reviewed in detail. The chronic relapsing nature of his disease, need for maintenance therapy, as well as the importance of compliance with medical therapy was also discussed. Distinction between a "step-up" approach and a "step-down" or 'proactive' strategy with a permanent model was also outlined. We discussed the risk factors for severe disease phenotypes which increase the risk of future surgery and complications. We discussed the elevated long-term risk of colon cancer and need for future surveillance colonoscopies to evaluate for dysplasia. I discussed the treatment options in detail including risks, benefits, and alternatives. Patient was started on mesalamine and mesalamine suppositories following her colonoscopy and called into the clinic with worsening symptoms for which she was started on prednisone 40 mg p.o. daily. On her previous visit we discussed dose escalation and she agreed upon medication of Entyvio which she started on 12/2023. She has now received 2 infusions with clinical improvement and is now established on every 2 weeks subcutaneous injection. Repeat fecal calprotectin on 4/2024 revealed significantly elevated levels. GI PCR was negative despite history of C. difficile and recent antibiotic usage. CSP was performed on 6/2024 with evidence of chronic active colitis in the distal colon with ulceration. Entyvio levels obtained with no Abs and therapeutic levels. Patient was deemed a secondary non-responder to Entyvio. We discussed the potential therapeutic changes and decieded to proceed with Skyrizi. She was induced on 8/2024 and appears to be doing well clinically. Fecal calp in 6/2025 was 41. CSP in 6/2025 was normal. She is feeling well and states that she is able to go out to events without concerns for having UC flare. Will have her continue Skyrizi q8 weeks. Will order fecal calp today.
2. Change in bowel habits: The patient reports a chronic history of constipation likely a consequence of opiate pain medications and previously treated with Movantik. On her initial visit with me on 5/2022, she was having irregular bowel movements with occasional diarrhea, constipation, and fecal incontinence. Colonoscopy performed on 3/2022 revealing cecal inflammation with pathology revealing acute active colitis. I recommended fiber supplementation and stool studies revealing C. difficile infection as well as abnormally high fecal calprotectin level. Patient underwent treatment for C. difficile but continues to have irregular bowel habits with mucoid stools and intermittent rectal bleeding. She had a recent visit to the emergency room with symptoms suggestive of acute gastroenteritis. Fecal calprotectin obtained with elevation prompting repeat colonoscopy performed with evidence of ulcerative colitis. We discussed there is still a potential for overlap of IBS-D and inflammatory bowel disease along with opioid-induced adverse effect. We will continue monitoring.
3. C. diff Colitis: The patient underwent a colonoscopy in 3/2022 with cecal biopsy showing acute colitis. We discussed the potential for NSAID induced colitis which he is currently take daily. GI PCR subsequently returned positive treated twice now with Vanc. x 14 days and again with vancomycin taper. Repeat C. difficile PCR positive 12/2022 for which she is pending approval for Dificid through the pharmaceutical company. Of note, E. coli was also positive for which she received treatment with ciprofloxacin. Repeat C. difficile PCR and cytotoxin cell assay was negative from June, 2023. Repeat GI PCR and C Diff PCR 5/2024 was negative.
4. GERD: The patient has typical reflux symptoms well controlled on omeprazole. Recent endoscopy on 3/2022 revealing a 4 cm sliding hiatal hernia with no significant esophagitis. We will continue current therapy; however, in the setting of recurrent C. difficile may need to consider anti-reflux surgery given association between PPI and enteric infections. She is doing well on Omeprazole 40mg once daily. will continue current regimen.
5. Abdominal pain: Patient reports right lower quadrant burning abdominal pain which has been ongoing. She reports pain despite taking prednisone and mesalamine which makes me suspect a noninflammatory etiology. She does have a history of chronic lower back pain and intervention which may be resulting in radiculopathy.
6. Perianal irritation: Patient reports perianal irritation with nodular folliculitis with occasional drainage. There is a possibility of a deep-seated abscess as well. She was given a trial of Bactrim and vancomycin prophylactically previously with improvement. No active complaints.
Plan:
Renew Skyrizi 360 mg/2.4 mL (150 mg/mL) Administer 360 mg subcutaneously with OBI on thigh or abdomen, week 12 and every 8 weeks
Fecal calprotectin
Renew omeprazole 40 mg Take 1 capsule by mouth once daily
Drink at least 64oz of water daily
Miralax titration recommended
Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Citrucel 1-2 tabs daily.)
Follow-up with P.A./N.P. in 3 months

Chief Complaint:
abnormal LFT's
History of Present Illness:
Very pleasant 32-year-old female here today for consultation regarding abnormal LFTs. She was in her normal state of health until recently blood work showed elevated LFTs with an AST and ALT around 40-60. Previously they have been normal. She has been on Mounjaro for diabetes and weight loss for the last 2 to 3 years and has lost about 80 pounds. After the blood work showed the abnormal LFTs she had a FibroScan which showed CAP of 207 but an kPa of 11 with a low IQR. She has no prior known history of liver disease. She also is currently being worked up for Graves' disease and has a pending appointment with endocrinology next month.

Assessment:
Broad differential regarding abnormal LFTs. The most puzzling part of the situation is the FibroScan which does not suggest any major fatty liver but does show liver scarring possibly of 2 or 3. She already has pending MRE next week. I appears to see what that shows. Ultimately she may require a liver biopsy. I will run full liver serologies today. We will also wait to see what endocrinology says regarding Graves' disease. She is agreeable to this plan and we will schedule clinic follow-up in 2 months.

Chief Complaint:
f/u GERD
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Rocha is a 48-year-old female presenting for follow up of GERD.
Last seen on 1/15/2025 for continued management of GERD symptoms. Outside records from 4/22/2025 reviewed from Methodist Stone Oak for patient presented for abdominal pain with history of acute diverticulitis. CT imaging was notable for kidney stones and a mild right-sided pyelonephritis.
Patient reports she is mainly looking to have a refill of her omeprazole. She has been taking 40 mg once daily and has been stable on that dose. She does report rebound symptoms of coming off the medication. Denies any associated dysphagia, unexplained weight loss, or melena. She is still working on weight loss and trying to workout though her hip pain seems to limit her.
In terms of constipation, she is reporting regular bowel movements with use of hydration. She does have occasional diarrhea for which she will take Imodium but this is rare.

Assessment:
Ms. Rocha is a 48-year-old female presenting for follow up of GERD, constipation.
Patient is overall doing well from a symptomatic standpoint in terms of her GERD and constipation. She is requesting omeprazole to be refilled at today's visit. We did discuss long-term potential for side effects and possibility of attempting to hide titrate down to lowest effective dose. Patient is electing to maintain current dose for now.
In terms of bowel movements, advised continued efforts towards hydration and adequate fiber intake. She may take either MiraLAX or Imodium depending on her need on a given day.
Plan:
Renew omeprazole 40 mg Take 1 capsule by mouth once a day, 30 minutes before the first meal of the day
Follow-up office visit in 1 year
James Alvarez, MD

Chief Complaint:
GERD/ IBS-C
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 71-year-old M referred by Dr. Williams who presents as a follow-up for GERD. Patient was seen by Dr. Chumley in 2019. Patient was seen on 3/2022 with worsening reflux symptoms while sleeping and after meals. He was taking Pantoprazole and Mylanta. On his visit on 5/2022 he started taking Nexium OTC with improvement. On his visit on 9/2022 he was doing well on OTC Nexium. On his visit on 3/2023 he was doing well on Rabeprazole 20mg PO daily. He reported two weeks prior he underwent surgery for tongue cancer s/p excision. On his visit on 4/2024 he was doing well on Rabeprazole 20mg PO daily. He reported some worsening constipation. He did change his diet given that he was pre-DM. On his visit on 6/2024 he reported increased bloating and burping with persistent constipation. On his visit on 11/2024 he continued to have dyspepsia and gas. He was given Flagyl for possible SIBO. On his visit on 2/2025 he began having daily BMs with soft stool consistency. He was taking fiber supplements and Miralax. He remained on Rabeprazole with good control of reflux. He was seen on 6/24/2025 and reported persistent bowel irregularity despite taking fiber supplements. He did start Lubiprostone and remains on Rabeprazole for reflux. He was seen on 7/29/2025 and reported experiencing lower abdominal cramping and pain last Tuesday/Wednesday, and on Friday he was on the verge of going to the ER/UC. Saturday morning, his pain subsided but he still felt tender. He took Dulcolax 4 tabs on Sunday with diarrhea which gave him relief. He was given Lubiprostone 8mcg twice daily, Citrucel 1tbsp once daily, Miralax 1capful once daily and he was doing well initially having a BM every 1-2 days. Gradually it got more prolonged. He was started on Linzess and reported diarrhea with urgency. He states that he faithfully took it for 2 weeks but 2 hours after taking the medication, he would have 4-5 bouts of diarrhea with urgency. He was seen on 8/20/2025 and reported taking Miralax 1 capful once daily, Citrucel tablets 2-3 times a day and IBGard 3 times daily and is having a bowel movement almost every day, although it is small amounts and stated it is very "unsatisfying." He is experiencing milder abdominal pain, bloating and incomplete emptying.
Currently, he reports last weekend he started having lower abdominal cramping and bloating and was very constipated. His symptoms persisted until Monday morning and he increased the Linzess to 145mcg which relieved his bowel movement and abdominal cramps. He is also taking IBGard 3 times a day.

Diagnosis:
GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease)
Family history of colon cancer in father
Chronic idiopathic constipation
Abdominal cramping
Assessment:
1. GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease) - The patient has a chronic history of GERD well-controlled with medications and lifestyle restrictions. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of reflux. He reports worsening symptoms typical of GERD recently with the addition of Mylanta and Protonix with worsening insomnia. He was previously on Nexium with relief, but was concerned about potential adverse effects. We discussed the potential long-term adverse effects of PPI therapy and I provided him with reassurance. He does not have alarm symptoms at this stage that warrants endoscopic evaluation. Although the patient is well controlled on Nexium his insurance approves Rabeprazole 20 mg p.o. daily which he has been doing with improved symptoms. We will plan to continue this therapy.
2. Family history of colon cancer in father - DX 70s/Personal history of colon polyps: The patient's last CSP was on 5/2018. CSP performed 6/2023 with multiple TAs and HPs. Recall in 3 yrs, 6/2026.
3. IBS-Constipation: DDx. includes medication induced v. chronic idiopathic constipation v. IBS-C v. slow transit constipation v. pelvic floor dysfunction v. metabolic derangements v. lack on fluid/fiber intake etc. We discussed the pathophysiology and natural history of the various causes of constipation. Further diagnostic testing includes laboratory testing, imaging, and endoscopic evaluation. We discussed the various symptoms of constipation including infrequency, excessive straining, incomplete emptying, hard stools, bloating, use of digital evacuation etc. Increase exercise as tolerated. I advised to maintain adequate hydration with at least 64 oz/day with exercise as tolerated. Stop lubiprostone, and will send in Linzess. I advised him to continue with Citrucel and Miralax and to titrate up to 3x a day. He had an episode of lower abdominal cramping last week and did not have a BM all week until he took Dulcolax on Sunday and had bowel movements. Trialed Linzess 145mcg once daily for 2 weeks with diarrhea 4x/day with urgency. He stopped taking it and started citrucel 2 tabs TID, miralax 1 capful once daily, and IB Gard TID with sensation of incomplete emptying and small BMs. We discussed lowering dose to 72 mcg once daily with IBGard and Citrucel only 2 tabs once daily. If he continues to have diarrhea with urgency can titrate down to every other day. I also advised him to add Miralax as needed. He had an episode of constipation this last weekend and increased his Linzess to 145mcg once daily on Monday with relief of his symptoms. We discussed increasing Linzess to 145mcg and he agrees.
4. Lower abdominal cramping: DDx. includes colonic spasms v. constipation v. diverticulitis v. appendicitis v. colitis v. IBD v. adhesions v. obstruction v. abdominal wall pain v. functional abdominal pain v. radiculopathy v. genitourinary/gynecological causes etc. We discussed the potential causes of the patientâ€™s symptoms and the diagnostic work-up which includes imaging and endoscopic evaluation. Recent CT AP demonstrated acute sigmoid diverticulitis, and he was treated with a course of Augmentin. He reports pain resolved. Last CSP was in 2023 and he is due for another next year.
Plan:
Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Benefiber, Metamucil, Citrucel.)
Miralax titration recommended
Drink at least 64oz of water daily
Renew and Increase Linzess 72 mcg to 145 mcg Take 1 capsule mouth, on an empty stomach, at least 30 minutes before a meal, ~same time each day
Renew rabeprazole 20 mg TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH EVERY DAY
Renew IBgard 90 mg Take 1-2 capsules by mouth three times a day as needed for abdominal pain
Follow-up with P.A./N.P. in 3 months
Other Intervention:
Additional Notes:
Thank you for allowing me to participate in the care of your patient. Please call for any questions or if I can be of any additional assistance.

Chief Complaint:
Yearly follow up, phlegm
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 49-year-old gentleman who was initially seen by Dr. Garza in February 2023 for an opinion regarding colon cancer screening. He underwent EGD colonoscopy in February 2023 which showed gastric previous surgery, internal hemorrhoids, otherwise normal. Nissen appeared to be partially done. If patient desires can consider surgical evaluation. Repeat colonoscopy recommended after 10 years. He has now transitioned his care to Dr. Guirl.
Patient presents today for follow-up visit. He had been feeling well up until 3 months ago when he started to develop increased phlegm, throat clearning and hoarseness of voice. He does report occasional heartburn and reflux. He is currently not taking anything for his symptoms. He is asking if his Nissen fundoplication should be redone. This was completed 20 years ago when he thinks it was done with Dr. Woodard. He also reports intermittent rectal pain and sometimes constipation with straining. He is currently not using anything over-the-counter for his symptoms and has not tried a high-fiber diet. He otherwise denies any issues with dysphagia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, gas or bloating, changes in bowel habits, blood in his stool, melena, unintentional weight loss or fevers.

Assessment:
The natural history, pathophysiology, and treatment of GERD was reviewed with the patient. Lifestyle and dietary modifications were also recommended, including weight loss, elevating head of the bed, avoiding meals 2 to 3 hours prior to bedtime, avoidance of tobacco products, and avoidance of "trigger foods". Will give him a trial of pantoprazole 40 mg daily 30 to 60 minutes prior to breakfast to see if this helps with the symptoms. He will follow-up with me in 3 months and we will see how he is doing at that time. If symptoms persist, can consider referral to ENT.
Patient would also like recommendations to see if his Nissen fundoplication needs to be redone. He thinks this was completed by Dr. Woodard 20 years ago. We will refer him to Dr. Woodard for further evaluation.
On rectal exam as well as anoscopy, the patient has internal hemorrhoids seen. His exam is otherwise unremarkable. The natural history, pathophysiology and treatment of hemorrhoids was reviewed with the patient. Patient was encouraged to use topical therapy such as Preparation H suppositories as needed. I have also prescribed Anusol suppositories. If his symptoms continue, hemorrhoid banding might be reasonable. He was given information on hemorrhoids and hemorrhoid banding. High fiber diet was recommended to prevent constipation and straining.
Plan:
Refer to Dr. Russell L. Woodard
Follow-up office visit in 3 months
High fiber diet (Beyond the Basics), patient education materials generated by EMR
Hemorrhoids, patient education materials generated by EMR

Chief Complaint:
constipation
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Boseman is a 73 year old patient who presents for a follow up evaluation.
Last Visit 3/14/2025: Since starting the alternating antibiotics for SIBO, symptoms have significantly improved overall. Still experiences recurrence of some symptoms on the week off antibiotics (having frequent small BMs throughout the morning, often waking her up in the early morning, 4am, ranging from Bristol 1-4. Also has a recurrence of bothersome bloating, belching, lower abdominal pressure, and nausea and sometimes vomiting.) This leads to decreased PO intake during that week, and she has continued with unintentional weight loss.
Asymptomatic on the antibiotics, able to eat well those weeks.
Today,
- Has been off alternating antibiotics for some time, but really did have significant improvement in her symptoms after this extended SIBO treatment.
-- Able to eat her own home-grown lettuce, tomatoes, etc, again. Very pleased with her response to this treatment.
- Past 2-3 weeks, back to her baseline of constipation, passing only a small amount of Bristol 1 stools daily.
-- Currently using a stool softener daily (without laxative).
-- When she hasn't been emptying fully, notices recurrence of burping and dyspepsia symptoms.
-- After a trial of stool softener/laxative combination medication, leading to her having a very good BM, finally feeling she had evacuated fully (after a few hours in the bathroom), dyspepsia/burping symptoms resolved.
- Has tried/failed Miralax, MOM, Mg citrate. Senna - works initially, leads to cramping after 3 days of consecutive use.
- Has not tried a prescription laxative in the past.
- Still using Zenpep daily, feels it works well for her.
- Also, Metoclopramide 5 mg, two tablets twice a day with meals. Feels this prevents more significant dyspepsia, bloating, burping symptoms.
- If not constipated, no dyspepsia, nausea, bloating, or abdominal pain.
- Denies blood in the stool, melena, abnormal weight loss.
- Notes, she has been diagnosed with an aggressive vulvular cancer, s/p surgical resection Aug 14th.
-- Chose to do a new study, for a DNA testing for the cancer. If it is positive, she will undergo radiation.

-More recently has been back to her prior basline bowel habits, constipation.
--Associated dyspepsia, burping, bloating, which resolves when able to have a good BM/evacuate fully.

This is a pleasant 31-year-old female with past medical history significant for anxiety disorder, depression, fatty liver who presents to clinic with chief complaint of elevated LFTs, hepatomegaly and chronic idiopathic constipation.

-Patient otherwise denies taking any herbal supplements, weight loss supplements, liver clinic supplements or protein supplements. She does report significant family history of liver disease in her mother and maternal grandmother, cirrhosis of the liver. She denies any binge or heavy consumption of alcohol currently or previously.
-She also complains of constipation with bowel movement every other day with sense of incomplete evacuation and does not take any fiber supplementation or laxative.
Recommendation:
The patient labs are elevated in a mixed pattern, ALT and alk phos pre-dominant with intact synthetic function. We discussed at length the differential diagnosis for elevated liver enzymes and the importance of differentiating abnormal liver enzymes from abnormal liver function. like medications v. alcohol v. NAFLD v. autoimmune hepatitis v. PBC v. PSC v. Wilson disease v. hemochromatosis v. alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency v. viral hepatitis etc.
I would like for the patient to obtain AMA to evaluate for autoimmune pathology/PBC and also fractionation of alkaline phosphatase although I suspect this is more fatty liver disease related and at the same time also obtain a hepatic function panel before my follow-up in 6 months. I suspect hepatomegaly is more likely driven by underlying obesity. We will obtain an abdominal x-ray to evaluate for stool burden, based on which we can consider initiating a bowel regimen with fiber and laxatives.
Plan:
Follow-up office visit in 6 months
Alkaline Phosphatase Isoenzyme
Abdomen X-ray 1 view (KUB) - 74018
Mitochondrial Antibody (AMA)
Liver Function Panel (HFP)
Additional Notes:
Thank you for allowing me to participate in the care of your patient. Please call for any questions or if I can be of any additional assistance.

Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
constipation
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a very pleasant 55-year-old Hispanic male who presents today for initial consultation.
The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, and irritable bowel syndrome. He underwent an internal hernia repair in 2016 at Medical City Dallas, which was done on an emergency basis. It sounds like he may have had compromised bowel or bowel obstruction. Of note, he has a large laparotomy scar in his midline.
The patient reports intermittent issues with left-sided gassiness, abdominal pain, and constipation. He can go two to three days without a bowel movement. He actually presented to the Baylor Scott & White McKinney ER for his symptoms in June. A CT scan revealed no acute abdominal process, and labs were unremarkable.
He is here today for follow-up. He still reports intermittent left-sided abdominal pain and constipation, however, not as severe as when he presented to the hospital several months ago. His last EGD and colonoscopy were performed in 1998 in Boston, Massachusetts. He cannot recall any specific findings on those procedures.
Family history is notable for a mother with stomach cancer.
I have reviewed his pertinent labs and imaging studies. The differential diagnosis includes intra-abdominal adhesions, neoplasia, stricturing disease, inflammatory bowel disease, and functional GI disease.
I will schedule him for an EGD and a colonoscopy to investigate his upper abdominal discomfort as well as for colon cancer screening. Furthermore, I will provide him with two weeks of Linzess samples to see if that helps with his symptomatology. I will try to log in to the HCA system to see if I can review his surgery that was performed in 2016.
The patient agrees with the plan as outlined.

Chief Complaint:
Abdominal pain
History of Present Illness:
Jaylen is a very pleasant 31-year-old male with a BMI of 29 that appears in excellent health and presents to the office today from his primary care doctor at the VA Medical Center Dr. Dar with abdominal pain. He began having symptoms around May 2025 for unclear reasons although he did undergo hip surgery a month prior. He did receive prophylactic antibiotics prior to the procedure but did not require them thereafter. He will develop episodes of severe epigastric abdominal pain that would range between 5 or 6 out of 10 to as high as 8 out of 10, sometimes so severe that it would awaken him at night. He describes no triggers, no predictable onset however symptoms do occur randomly and are not alleviated by any typical measures. He did however state there was some improvement at least in the degree of discomfort he was experiencing when he was prescribed 20 mg of omeprazole for 14 days. He was seen and evaluated at the VA Medical Center/emergency department for which she was told the labs and imaging were unremarkable. He denies any solid or liquid dysphagia, no weight changes, no melena or hematochezia. He relates no known history in his family of gastrointestinal malignancies

Assessment:
31-year-old healthy male with a BMI of 29 with several months of epigastric abdominal pain and bloating with a history of reflux intermittently. Etiology remains unclear however his symptoms can be significant, no overt triggers but they do awaken him at night. This is concerning for potentially ulcer disease versus functional etiology or changes related to SIBO from his antibiotics used for surgery in April. All of this was discussed with him today, I recommend a low gas healthy diet at this time, I have recommended starting pantoprazole 40 mg daily empirically and proceeding with endoscopy to evaluate for ulcer disease. I recommend evaluation for SIBO also
Plan:
Lose weight with diet/exercise as discussed. Attempt 10% body weight loss over 6 months.*
Diet as tolerated
pantoprazole 40 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth once a day 30 min before breakfast
My office will obtain prior records from hospital
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)

Chief Complaint:
Iron deficiency anemia
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Katherine Phillips is a very pleasant 43 yo WF seen at the request of CNM Kathleen Donaldson for iron-deficiency anemia.  Labs sent over reviewed:
(8/4/25) - Hgb 10.4 (normal MCV); CBC otherwise fine; CMP normal; normal thyroid function testing and A1c; B12 normal.
Ms. Phillips showed me additional labs in her notebook of prior results:
(8/5/2025) - Iron 28, ferritin 4.37, transferrin saturation 5 all low; elevated TIBC at 548.
For comparison to prior labs, Hgb/ Hct were normal on 6/20/2022, 2/12/2018, and 9/20/2017.
Work-up initiated after she felt lightheaded while on vacation with her father at the Biltmore in Asheville (walking the gardens).  Pre-syncopal and/ or orthostatic symptoms.  EMS assessment negative and she declined the ambulance ride to the hospital.  Persistent orthostatic symptoms since that time (even when sitting).  Denies chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, palpitations.
No overt GI bleeding, change in bowel habits/ stool caliber, unintentional weight loss.  UGI ROS negative except for vague nausea that developed at the same time of the orthostatic symptoms.  It has persisted but does not prevent him from eating.  No family h/o GI malignancies.
No prior EGD or colonoscopy.  No regular NSAID use.  She did show me a result panel from stool diagnostic testing done in 8/2021 - positive for various things including H. pylori.  She never did anything about it in regards to treatment.
Finally when questioned about menstrual periods, the patient does have menometrorrhagia present over the past 3 years.  She can bleed for 3+ weeks straight at a time.  Pelvic ultrasound just completed - she is awaiting a call about results.  Mrs. Phillips also reports receiving the 1st of two doses of IV iron (Venofer).

Assessment:
Patient reports history of chronic hepatitis B, inactive and has been followed by Dr. Glombicki but not in last couple of years. His PCP's note indicated that he has CHB since 2016.  We do not have HBV labs for review. He had HCV Ab negative from his PCP 3/24.
History of Hepatitis B infection, chronic. HB E Ag = positive / negative / pending. HBV DNA = pending / IU/mL. Discussed mode of transmission, complications and natural history of the disease. Patient with chronic HBV can be infected with hepatitis Delta (HDV) commonly via sexual contacts or drug use. HDV can cause a severe hepatitis, serious consequences with super-infection. Discussed mode of transmission of HDV. Patient with chronic liver diseases should avoid raw sea foods, herbal products, alcohol and should not consume more than 2000 mg of acetaminophen per 24 hour period. Need work up for other chronic liver disease. Need hepatitis A vaccination if not already done so in the past.  Once labs for CHB has confirmed CHB, would consider fibrosis assessment with elastography
Blood in stool. Blood is bright red in nature and is outside of stool. The source for the bleeding could be from hemorrhoids, anal fissure, mucosal tear, rectal ulcer, proctitis/colitis, colon polyps, juvenile polyps and malignancy. Would recommend colon evaluation. He reports that he had colonoscopy done at Sugar Land Medical Center in SL in 2023 but does not recall the physician's name.  Discussed colonoscopy versus sigmoidoscopy and barium enema. Discussed risks, benefits, complications and alternatives. Recommended at least sigmoidoscopy.  Patient opts for no evaluation and declined rectal exam.
Fatty liver on ultrasound.  8/25 TSH 1.18, HDL 27, chol 144, TG 213, LDL 86,, Cr 0.78, AST 16, ALT 17, alk phos 109, Hgb 14 MCV 94.2, platelet 222. Discussed MASLD and CHB.  Recommend lifestyle modification, change in diet and increase exercise to decrease weight. Patient can follow up with primary care physician for evaluation prior to embarking on rigorous exercise program.

Ethelle Forrest is a 77 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit. Mrs. Forrest, a patient with a history of iron deficiency anemia and a blood clot, presents for evaluation of potential gastrointestinal blood loss. She has been receiving iron infusions for her anemia. The patient reports a 40-year history of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with cycles of gas, constipation, and diarrhea occurring two to three times per week.
Mrs. Forrest denies any visible blood in her stool or dark stools. She also denies any heavy menstrual cycles. The patient's last colonoscopy was performed 10 years ago. No cardiac or pulmonary history.

Chief Complaint:
liver lesion
History of Present Illness:
Kevin Critchlow is a 37-year-old male who presents to Gastroenterology for evaluation of a liver lesion discovered incidentally on CT scan. The patient reports a history of hematospermia for approximately 3 months, which prompted the initial imaging.
The CT scan, performed at ARA in San Marcos, revealed a well-circumscribed liver lesion measuring 2 to 2.5 centimeters (we do not have reports yet). The patient denies any symptoms related to the liver lesion, including abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or blood in the stool. He reports feeling physically healthy overall.
In addition, he reports having routine lab work checked by his PCP prior to the CAT scan at Totals Ment Healthcare in Kyle, Texas and was told lab work was unremarkable. He does not know if liver tests were checked at that time. We will also request records for these.
The patient's hematospermia, which led to the CT scan, has since resolved. He attributes this to inflammation caused by alcohol consumption and other substances. As a result, he has abstained from alcohol for the past few months. Prior to this, he consumed approximately 6 to 8 drinks per week, occasionally up to 10, primarily mixed drinks or beer, with some wine. He also reports rare use of recreational THC.
He denies any significant medical history, chronic diseases, or previous cancer diagnoses. He works remotely for a bank and has not experienced any impact on his daily functioning due to his current health concerns.
Allergies
- No known allergies

- Father: Aggressive prostate cancer, prostate removed, age 67

Unclear if recent LFTs obtained. Differential diagnosis includes liver hemangioma, focal nodular hyperplasia, hepatocellular adenoma, liver infectious cyst, regenerative nodules, HCC, etc.
- Order MRI of the liver for further characterization of the lesion.
- Request CT scan records from ARA in San Marcos.
- Request lab work results from Total Men's Healthcare in Kyle.
- If liver function tests are not included in the available lab work, order CMP with AFP.
- Review MRI results to determine need for follow-up visit.
- If lesion is benign, patient to follow up with primary care physician.
- Encouraged continued alcohol cessation or decrease consumption.

Chief Complaint:
anemia, discuss colonoscopy
History of Present Illness:
Thomas Heine is a 54-year-old male with psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis who presents to Gastroenterology clinic for evaluation of anemia and unintentional weight loss.
Over the past few months he has experienced unprecedented 20-pound weight loss despite unchanged diet and consumption patterns. Recent bowel habit changes over the past couple weeks include decreased frequency from daily movements to passing "a small piece of stool" initially, followed by larger accumulated stool later in the day that he describes as "18 to 24 inches long." He notes accompanying change in gas odor, describing it as "fouled" and "molderous." He uses milk of magnesia as needed for hard stools caused by high fiber intake, taking just enough to ease passage without causing liquid stools.
He denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, blood or black color in stool, heartburn, or prior GI procedures. He continues daily bowel movements and maintains ability to work daily. His psoriasis is managed with topical ointment. He reports undiagnosed condition on left foot, possibly dyshidrosis, with "huge, very itchy, burning blisters that rupture and heal" in recurring cycles.
Outside lab work on 7/24/2025 with iron 62, iron saturation 26%, ferritin 354, PSA 0.20, creatinine 1.3, sodium 140, potassium 4.6, calcium 9.1, albumin 4.4, T. bili 0.3, ALP 83, AST 17, ALT 13, WBC 5.9, hemoglobin 12, hematocrit 36.8, MCV 92.5, PLT 226. No prior lab work on file for comparison at this time.
No known FHx of GI conditions or any cancers. No prior abdominal surgeries.

Assessment:
54-year-old man with unintentional weight loss, mild anemia, and altered bowel habits on background of psoriasis and tobacco use.
1. Unintentional weight loss - 20-pound loss over past few months, with altered bowel habit. No prior endoscopic procedures. No known FHx of cancers. Differential diagnosis includes primary GI malignancy such as colon cancer, depression, malabsorptive disorder, lung cancer given smoking history, H. pylori infection, peptic ulcer disease, etc.
- Schedule endoscopy and colonoscopy to evaluate for gastrointestinal causes.
- SUPREP bowel prep ordered.
- If endoscopy and colonoscopy negative, consider CT scan from top to bottom for other causes.
- Follow up on weight trends and repeat lab work in few months if procedures declined or negative.
Normocytic anemia - Mild anemia of unknown etiology, no overt iron deficiency. Does take celecoxib on regular basis.
- Proceed with endoscopy and colonoscopy to evaluate for gastrointestinal sources of blood loss.
- Monitor hemoglobin levels with follow-up lab work at follow-up visit.
Tobacco use - 30-year smoking history, half pack daily, significant risk factor.
- Strongly encourage smoking cessation.
- PCP to consider lung cancer screening given smoking history.
Follow-Up
- Gastroenterology clinic in 3 months.
Plan:
Follow-up office visit in 3 months

Risks and benefits statement: The procedure and its preparation, benefits, alternatives, and limitations were explained to the patient or legal guardian. The risks and potential complications including but not limited to perforation, bleeding, infection, missed lesion, aspiration and other complications of sedation were reviewed. The patient or legal guardian verbalized understanding and wishes to proceed.
This patient has been evaluated and is a candidate for an Outpatient Surgery Center.

Chief Complaint:
Epigastric pain
History of Present Illness:
This 35-year-old male is referred by his primary care physician, Dr. Rika Varani, for evaluation of epigastric pain. The onset of his symptoms was approximately one month ago. He reports a sensation of bloating in the upper abdomen accompanied by pain. The pain is not severe but is elicited and exacerbated by palpation of the epigastric area. He has also experienced a sore throat, which he likens to the sensation of an impending flu, and a change in bowel habits characterized by the sensation of needing to defecate without being able to pass stool. These symptoms began around the same time as the abdominal discomfort. He also reports new-onset, constant headaches for the past month.
He was prescribed Omeprazole by his PCP about a month ago. He notes that if he misses a dose, the epigastric pain seems to worsen. He is unsure if the medication is providing complete relief, but he does notice a negative change when he does not take it.
The patient's symptoms are occurring in the context of new-onset anxiety, which began in July after he was diagnosed with high cholesterol. Following this diagnosis, he began experiencing chest pain and left arm pain, which he feared was cardiac in origin. He was prescribed Atorvastatin. He presented to an emergency room at Methodist where he was evaluated by Dr. Momin. A cardiac workup, including an echocardiogram and a stress test, was performed and the results were normal, ruling out a cardiac etiology for his chest pain. He reports his anxiety has improved somewhat with this reassurance, but he is still struggling with it. He denies any prior history of anxiety.
Prior Tests Reviewed:
- Complete metabolic panel and complete blood count from 07/30/2025 were normal.
- Cardiac troponin was checked during a prior ER visit and was presumably normal.
- An abdominal ultrasound from 08/14/2025 was reported as normal.
- A chest scan from August was noted to be okay, with a subtle elevation of the right hemidiaphragm.
- Echocardiogram and stress test were normal.

Chief Complaint:
elevated lft
History of Present Illness:
Paulette Sauln is a 77 year old female patient who is seen today for an initial visit.
She was admitted to the hospital August 13 with acute onset abdominal pain.
At admission she was noted to have an alk phos of 459, AST of 43, ALT of 842 and a total bilirubin of 1.3.
She had abdominal ultrasound which was grossly unremarkable. She had MRCP which shows moderate biliary ductal dilatation although no ductal stone or obstructing lesion was identified. She did have some mild hepatic steatosis.
In the hospital was discussed with therapeutic endoscopist who felt like given resolution of pain and improving numbers could be followed as outpatient.
After discharge she had repeat LFTs done which revealed near normalization of her numbers 8/22 save for mild ALT elevation of 71.
Since then she has been feeling well with no abdominal pain. Denies any nausea or vomiting.
No constipation or diarrhea.
No hematochezia in terms of melena.
She stated colonoscopy and is due for another one in 2028.
Denies any dysphagia or odynophagia.
She says she was told to stop her Cardizem and ezetemibe at dc
I reviewed her chronic liver workup which was grossly unremarkable. She did have an elevated ferritin but a low TSAT

Assessment:
This is a 77-year-old female who presents to establish care after admitted to the hospital with acute abdominal pain that resolved spontaneously.
In the hospital she was noted to have significant elevated enzymes. Abdominal ultrasound was normal but MRCP revealed biliary ductal dilatation.
However LFTs trended back down and chronic liver disease workup was negative.
Her follow-up outpatient LFTs reveal near normalization.
Presumably she had some biliary sludge which passed.
Will repeat her LFTs and repeat her MRI. If ongoing signs of bili ductal dilatation will proceed with EUS plus minus ERCP. Otherwise if normal no further workup is needed

Diagnoses:
Chronic constipation
Mucus in stool
Abdominal bloating
Heartburn
Assessment:
DDx mucus in stool includes IBS, constipation, hemorrhoids, IBD, cancer, others. Will focus on improving constipation. Will treat possible hemorrhoids. Recommend regular, gentle cleaning. To monitor for any blood in stool or mucus. To work on improving diet. Increase water intake and fiber in diet. If no improvement or symptoms worsening, to proceed with Colonoscopy next.
DDx of the patient's constipation includes thyroid disease, medications, obstructions, narrowings, slow transit constipation, defecatory disorders, and others. Discussed increase water intake and fiber in diet. Discussed fiber supplement daily. Discussed Miralax titration. Samples of Miralax given.
DDx of the patient's bloating includes but is not limited to celiac disease, malabsorption, IBD, IBS, GERD, functional dyspepsia, Pancreatic Insufficiency, H Pylori, and others. Discussed anti-gas measures. Will work on improving constipation. May try IBgard and probiotic. Samples of IBgard given.
DDx of the patient's heartburn includes GERD, NERD, Hiatal Hernia, H Pylori, Peptic Ulcer Disease, or others. Infrequent. Discussed anti-reflux measures. To try Pepcid PRN.
Plan:
Lose weight with diet/exercise as discussed. Attempt 10% body weight loss over 6 months.*
Consider taking fiber supplement such as Metamucil (psyllium husk - best at bulking), Benefiber (wheat dextrin with prebiotic - can help good gut flora), OR Citrucel (methylcellulose - less gas producing) daily to help stool consistency. Would start the fiber supplement at 2 tablets a day (or 1/2 tbsp a day in water) and increase slowly to 4 tablets, or 2 tablets twice daily (1 tbsp a day). Slow titration may help decrease gas and bloating that can occur when first taking.
For constipation, take Miralax 1/2-1 capful powder once or twice daily. Take on routine basis to avoid constipation. Adjust dose and frequency as needed for desired stool consistency and frequency.
Monitor diet closely and avoid foods that can worsen symptoms, such as: foods high in carbohydrates (fruits and fruit juices), spicy foods, fried foods, and milk products. Consider trying IBGard OTC for gas/bloating. Take 1-2 up to 3 times a day as needed. Consider probiotic daily.
Hydrocortisone Acetate 25 mg Insert 1 suppository into rectum at bedtime for 14 days
Ultrasound Abdomen Complete - 76700 SEND TO TOUCHSTONE PLANO
Follow-up in 2 months. Consider Colonoscopy and possible EGD (upper endoscopy) next if ongoing or worsening symptoms.

Chief Complaint:
+Cologuard.  C/O constipation
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Lively is an 89-year-old female seen for fatigue and anemia. She was recently discharged from select rehab after CVA 8/3/2025. History is also notable for CKD 4 and MGUS as well as DM with endorgan disease. She was admitted 7/10/2025 to acute inpatient setting after presenting for shortness of breath and fatigue for 2 weeks. Patient CT of the head showed a new 1.7 cm intraparenchymal hemorrhage of the right occipital lobe. She was seen by surgery but did not require intervention. She was managed medically. Hemoglobin at the time of discharge from inpatient rehab 8/3/2025 was 9.3 with MCV 80.8
Patient comes to clinic today after positive Cologuard was found by PCP. She has a sibling with colorectal cancer. She has had some constipation that she has complained to her son about but apparently this is long-term as patient reports that she typically takes medications entirely for constipation. She reported to her son several days ago that she had some blood in her stool but denies it today to both me and her son. Her son reports that she is from a family of 20 most of whom had cancer. In addition she has lost significant weight over the last several months but this occurs in the setting of a hospitalization. Since her discharge from rehab she has lost from 100 pounds to 96 pounds today. Patient's son reports that she is eating well at home. Patient denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. She has had significant fatigue.

Assessment:
Ms. Lively is an 89-year-old female with family history of colorectal cancer seen for fatigue and anemia and positive Cologuard. Hemoglobin is 9.3 stable from approximately 2 months prior at 8.5. She has had weight loss of approximately 4 pounds since discharge from rehab on 8/3 approximately 6 weeks ago despite a good appetite. CT chest abdomen and pelvis performed in January 2025 showed no obvious lesion in the colon. I discussed with her son that she is extremely high risk for anesthesia right now but there is obvious concern for possible malignancy given her iron deficiency anemia, positive Cologuard, family history. We agreed that in this acute poststroke. We will watch her carefully over the next month for continuing weight loss. If she loses more than approximately 3 pounds in the next month we will proceed to colonoscopy. We will also recheck her hemoglobin today to ensure that it is not worsening. If it is worsening would also recommend colonoscopy. Otherwise, we will see her back in 2 months and likely perform colonoscopy at that time. Son is aware of the risk of anesthesia as well as my grave concern for colorectal cancer. We discussed potentially repeating CT scan abdomen today but her most recent creatinine was 3.67 so this is not feasible.
Plan:
Follow-up with PCP for elevated blood pressure reading*
Complete Blood Count (CBC) without Diff.
Follow-up office visit in 2 months

Chief Complaint:
This is a consultation for a 36-year-old female with a chief complaint of chronic loose stools and significant unintentional weight loss since May 2025.
History of Present Illness:
Latesha is a 36-year-old female who presents for evaluation of a new onset of altered bowel habits and weight loss.
Latesha reports the onset of loose bowels in mid-May 2025. Initially, she experienced multiple loose bowel movements throughout the day, but the pattern has since changed to a single, explosive loose bowel movement first thing in the morning. She describes the stool consistency as typically a Bristol Stool Chart type 5, but has had episodes of type 7. She denies any associated mucus or blood in the stool. There is no nocturnal diarrhea. She reports a sense of urgency in the morning but denies significant abdominal cramping or pain. This represents a significant change from her baseline, which was a normal, formed bowel movement (type 2-3) daily. She also reports significant unintentional weight loss, from 140 pounds in May 2025 to her current weight of 114 pounds. This is associated with a decreased appetite. She has also been experiencing anxiety and depression, for which she was started on Wellbutrin. She notes the Wellbutrin has a constipating effect, and if she were to stop it, the diarrhea would return.
She has no upper gastrointestinal symptoms such as acid reflux or upper abdominal pain. She has tried dietary modifications, including eliminating dairy and consuming prebiotics like kimchi and kefir, without any noticeable improvement in her symptoms. She is a flight attendant and travels internationally, most recently to Mexico.
Her history is notable for taking isotretinoin for acne from April 2024 to August 2024; however, she experienced no gastrointestinal side effects while on the medication. She also had two episodes of illness (strep throat, bronchitis) between November 2024 and January 2025, for which she completed two courses of antibiotics. She has a history of intermittent skin lesions on her arm, which were previously biopsied with inconclusive results.
Due to low ferritin levels, she has received two intravenous iron (Venofer) infusions within the last month and is scheduled for follow-up blood work.

Assessment:
Chronic diarrhea
Unintentional weight loss
Iron deficiency/low ferritin
Loss of appetite
Assessment:
- Chronic diarrhea and weight loss: The primary concern is chronic diarrhea since May 2025, associated with a significant 26-pound weight loss and poor appetite. The differential diagnosis is broad and includes infectious etiologies such as post-infectious irritable bowel syndrome, Clostridium difficile infection (given her antibiotic use earlier in the year), or parasitic infection like Giardia. Inflammatory bowel disease, such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, is also a consideration, especially given the significant weight loss and systemic symptoms. Her dermatologic manifestations could potentially be an extra-intestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, although they are non-specific. My suspicion for Crohn's disease is low given the absence of abdominal pain. We discussed these possibilities.
- Iron deficiency: Her ferritin is low, and she has required intravenous iron infusions. This may be related to malabsorption from her gastrointestinal process.
- Procedure counseling: I have discussed the rationale, risks, and benefits of performing both an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and a colonoscopy. I explained that the colonoscopy is crucial for evaluating the colon for inflammation, and the esophagogastroduodenoscopy will allow for examination of the upper gastrointestinal tract, which can also be a source of malabsorption and weight loss. I explained the sedation process and the low-risk nature of the procedures. I also noted that at her age, a colonoscopy would serve as an early screening for colon cancer, which is recommended for African American individuals. She understands the plan and agrees to proceed.
Plan:
I will provide a stool collection kit today to test for infectious etiologies, including Clostridium difficile, Giardia, and other pathogens. I emphasized the importance of returning the sample promptly.
We will schedule an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy for a comprehensive evaluation. This will allow for direct visualization and biopsies of the upper and lower gastrointestinal tract to rule out inflammatory bowel disease or other causes of her symptoms.
She will need a responsible adult to drive her home after the procedures.
Follow up will be scheduled after the procedures to discuss the results and further management.
I reviewed my overall clinical impression, diagnostic strategy and treatment plan with the patient at length. She voiced understanding.
Plan:
Fecal calprotectin
Gastrointestinal Pathogen / GPP (QDx and Genesis)

Assessment:
Patient is a 60-year-old white female who presents to our office for follow-up on her GERD, elevated liver function tests her abdominal ultrasound and her labs. She has a history of colon polyps, type II DM, diverticulosis with episodes of diverticulitis, FLD, GERD, hemochromatosis, HTN. She was started on pantoprazole 20 mg daily approximately 6 weeks ago for her GERD symptoms. She reports that she immediately had good relief, no longer having substernal pain or reflux symptoms. She did state that the pharmacy ran out of her medication so she has been out for the past 5 to 7 days. She reports since being off her medication her substernal burning has returned. Therefore she feels the medication was working well and would like to continue. No indication for EGD at this time. She has also stopped her GLP-1 medication as she feels it was not helping her with weight loss. She did state that on Friday night she started with some left lower quadrant abdominal pain and diarrhea. She states the pain and diarrhea is ongoing today, has a history of diverticulosis as well as diverticulitis. We discussed need for CT scan today. Patient denies any hematochezia, no melena, no rectal pain or bleeding. She has not had any nausea, no weight loss, no dysphagia, no hemoptysis.
We discussed her ultrasound which showed mildly increased hepatic echogenicity to include hepatic steatosis.. She has been restarted to have FibroScan done with our office. She had labs on 9/4/2025 that showed inconclusive hep B and hep C series, updated labs ordered today.
We will continue on PPI for 3 to 6 months and then can consider weaning dose as able. Patient will continue to work on weight loss, is seeking out a nonsurgical bariatric clinic.
Plan:
Concerns for acute diverticulitis, CT ordered today, continue PPI daily, will list for fibroscan and repeat hep labs.
CT Abdomen and Pelvis WITH and WITHOUT contrast - 74178
Hepatitis B Core Total Ab
Hepatitis B Core IgM Ab
Hepatitis C Antibody with Reflex to Quantitative Real-time PCR
Continue current Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI) as instructed.
GERD diet, education provided

Chief Complaint:
GERD
History of Present Illness:
11/2023:
67-year-old woman previous patient of Dr. Lacey transitioning care to me due to his retirement. Patient has a history of chronic acid reflux and esophageal stricture requiring dilations in the past. She is currently on omeprazole 20 mg daily. Patient is also up-to-date on colorectal cancer screening. Last colonoscopy in 2022 with no polyps with a recommendation to repeat in 10 years. She recently had a stool study performed which showed blood in the stool. She denies any overt GI bleeding. She is also complaining about progressively worsening dysphagia to solids only. She recently found out she had a clavicle fracture after she sleepwalked an injury.
10/30/2024 (Kelsie):
68 yr old female presents to clinic for abnormal bowel movement/nausea
Pt reports intermittent nausea after eating for the past 2-3 weeks.
Has had a few episodes of vomiting. Denies epigastric pain, acid reflux/heartburn, dysphagia. Denies any NSAID use.
Pt is compliant with Omeprazole 20 mg QD
Pt reports shoulder replacement coming up 11/11
Pt reports had 1 BM with "specks" of blood 10 days ago and more loose than normal. No recurrence since. She has constipation often, and believes she did prior to abnormal BM. Pt reports no recurrence of bleeding. Recent CBC with PCP normal.
3/12/2025 Follow up: Denies rectal bleeding. States that reflux symptoms are not entirely well-controlled on omeprazole 40 mg. She is also worried about the potential side effects including but not limited to osteoporosis osteopenia given her steroid use. She denies dysphagia at this point. No other GI symptoms at this point.
09/12/2025 (Kelsie):
69 yr old female presents to clinic for 6 month follow up.
Pt reports that she took Voquezna for > 2 months and was having heartburn/burning in throat despite regular use of the medication. Pt changed back to Pantoprazole last month (~ 08/15/25) - she reports having some burning in her throat and upper chest still but better compared to when on Voquezna. She has this sx every 2-3 days or so. Pt also reports more intermittent dysphagia - believes worse in past few month - feels like things get stuck in upper esophagus. She is on a chronic inhaler and states sometimes feels like she has some abnormal sensation in throat area when she uses this. Denies odynophagia.
Pt c/o persistent constipation. Pt states that she has BM daily but can often be hard/require straining. Pt drinks abt 40 oz of water daily. She is trying to increase fiber intake - more berries and veggies over several months with no change. Takes Mg for sleep.
Follows with Cardiology Dr. Mottl. Follows with Pulmonology/sarcoidosis specialist. Pt used O2 after Pseudomonas infection last april - she reports has not needed O2 for past several months. However, has had progressively increased SOB in past month or so - going to see specialist in Houston

Assessment:
69 yr old female wiht PMHx GERD, esophageal stricture, asthma, sarcoidosis present to clinic for acid reflux.
Acid reflux - Pt trialed Voquezna after last OV and now on Pantoprazole with persistent acid reflux sxs - reports that she felt like Omeprazole is what controlled sxs best in past year so will have resume this. If sxs not better controlled after 2 weeks back on this, will trial adding Pepcid in PM prior to PPI BID due to her concern for SEs. Pt advised to update clinic on her sxs in 2 weeks
Dysphagia - solid/pill dysphagia worsening in past few months. Pt reports increased burning in upper chest/throat area with this - she is on inhaler with steroid component? possible candida esophagitis with burning increased vs recurrent stricture. Recommend EGD to evaluate further with dilation if indicated. However, pt also reports that she has had worsening SOB in past month or so - she is pending seeing a new Pulm in Houston next month. Due to sxs and eval pending, we discussed waiting until she has further workup and pt agreeable with this. Will consider EGD in hospital if needed based on pulmonary status
Pt c/o persistent constipation. She is on chronic Mg at home - we discussed trial of increasing dose of this vs Miralax with titration for tx of constipation. Wok on increasing water intake.
Plan:
Recommend checking your Magnesium dose at home - if on low dose can increase to see if this helps your constipation (take 400-800 mg). If you are already on higher dose, then would recommend trial of Miralax for constipation - start 1 cap daily and adjust every 2-3 days based on response
Drink at least 64oz of water daily
Recommend EGD - pending pulmonology evaluation next month so will wait until this is completed to proceed.
Recommend switching PPI back to Omeprazole 40 mg daily as this gave best control in past year. Please take for 2 weeks then update clinic - if your symptoms are persistent then will add Pepcid 40 mg in the evening while pending EGD
Follow-up office visit in 2 months

Chief Complaint:
4 Months Follow Up
History of Present Illness:
Heather Brinich Langlois is a 41 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.
With PMHx of Ehlers Danlos syndrome, Ankylosing spondylitis, Psoriatic arthritis, OSA on CPAP, HTN, DM
This is a patient we see for colonic Crohn's and GERD.
She initially established with us in February 2016 presenting with chronic diarrhea, hematochezia, fecal urgency, fecal incontinence, abdominal cramping and nausea. C. difficile was negative. Underwent EGD and colonoscopy March 2016 and her colon showed a normal-appearing TI, patchy superficial ulcerations and erythema throughout the colon but not in the rectum. Colon biopsy in the right colon showed focal chronic inflammation within lamina propria acute activity not identified, and the transverse colon biopsy showed focal active colitis with superficial ulceration, the left colon and rectum were normal. IBD serology lab panel was negative. She was started on Uceris (budesonide) 9mg daily and Lialda 4.8 g daily. November 2016 she developed an anal fissure that progressed to an abscess that required drainage/seton placement. Was placed on Imuran 50 mg daily and took this until 2018 when she wanted to d/c as she felt it was giving her diarrhea/headaches. Noted long history of intermittent infections (on Enbrel) and was frequently on/off Uceris. In February 2019 was tried on Sulfasalazine 1g TID and had d/c it by March 2020. She had held off on anti-TNF alpha drug due to wanting to harvest her eggs for fertility treatment. Repeat colonoscopy May 2020 showed patchy erythema and ulcerations from cecum to sigmoid rectal area. Was started on Stelara May 29th 2020 with her initial infusion, had insurance coverage issues and first injection was August 1st 2020 and then was hospitalized with COVID September 2020 and never went back to taking it, despite our recommendations. In June 2021 she was hospitalized for necrotic wounds from a tummy tuck she had done in Mexico. She was lost to follow up after August 2021 until she returned to see is in October of 2024. She had been admitted at University Health in January 2024 at University. Was placed on budesonide 9 mg in the hospital. Colonoscopy at University Hospital did show small scattered aphthous ulcers throughout the colon and TI consistent with Crohn's. Her MR enterography of the small bowel January 2024 was negative for inflammation in the small bowel. At time of her October 2024 visit when she came back to see she was placed back on Budesonide 9mg daily for 60 days and discussed Skrizi.
Her last visit was February 2025 with Dr. McMyler and at that time she was still taking Budesonide 9mg daily (even though we only sent a 60 day supply), she reported having 2-4 BMs a day, no blood, but did have some fecal urgency. Noted she was on Ozempic and A1c had improved but her weight was stable/unchanged
Last visit May 2025 with me.
GERD is managed with pantoprazole 40 mg and famotidine 40 mg.
Has had prior discussed with recommendation to start on Skyrizi for Crohn's disease management; noted patient was currently on Enbrel for her joint disease. Patient did not want to switch. She was advised to try tapering off of the budesonide slowly and February 2025 was placed on Lialda 4.8 g a day. If she flares then we will need to change her biologic.
At time of May 2025 visit, patient had successfully tapered off the Budesonide and started on Mesalamine 4 pills daily. She reported 3-4 BMs daily with somewhat formed/somewhat loose stools, starts off formed and then becomes more loose. No blood or mucus. No abdominal pain or cramping.
On June 8th graduates with MBA
Has history of Ehler Danlos as well as ankylosing spondylitis. Is on Enbrel for her joint pain/AS and seeing Dr. Rosenberg (Rheumatologist) and also follows with pain specialist for chronic knee/back pain and an orthopedic surgeon. Noted she has been on Cimzia and her Humira in the past for her arthritis.
Currently, patient reports did meet with her rheumatologist Dr rosenberg last thursday and discussed that with her ankylosing spondylitis that the skyrizi would not cover that, so may not be the best choice for her.  She feels that she is doing okay on the Lialda.  Says every few days will have an episode of fecal urgency  but otherwise BMs have been doing well.  Has a BM when she wakes up in the morning and then 2-3 throughout the day and then one in the evening and are formed. No mucus or blood. Takes the Lialda 2 in the morning and 2 in the evening.    She tells me that she has gained weight, despite being on Mounjaro. Tells me that for her, this is sometimes a symptom that something is wrong with her body and that there may be inflammation going on.
Review of records:
-- EGD/colonoscopy 3/24/2016. EGD showed gastritis biopsies negative for H. pylori celiac negative. GE junction was a break in the mucosa and a 3 mm ulcer consistent with ulcerative esophagitis. Colonoscopy normal. TI patchy superficial ulcerations and erythema throughout the colon but not in the rectum. Random biopsies obtained. Internal hemorrhoids. Colon biopsies showed focal chronic inflammation within the lamina. Acute activity not identified. Transverse colon showed focal active colitis with superficial ulcerations this could be postinfectious versus NSAIDs. Cannot rule out Crohn's but IBD serology was negative
-- Colonoscopy and 9/29/2016 normal. TI patchy ulcerations throughout the colon worse in the descending and sigmoid colon. Ulcerations appear deeper on the left side. Mild irritation granular appearing mucosa in the rectum. Biopsies sent for CMV.
-- MR angiogram abdomen 10/31/2016 prominent enhancement of soft tissue thickening in the perianal region without fluid collection no fistulas or deep abscess. Hepatomegaly with hepatic steatosis 19 cm.
-- EGD/colonoscopy 9/24/2018 EGD showed reflux esophagitis nodular gastritis H. pylori negative celiac negative. Colonoscopy showed patchy erythema and ulcers from the cecum to the sigmoid colon with the left side being worse than the right. No ulcers in the TI of the rectum. Biopsy showed focal active colitis with cryptitis in the cecum transverse and left side of the colon. Rectum spared. Active disease throughout upper predominantly in the descending and sigmoid colon
-- EGD/colonoscopy 5/13/2020 EGD showed reflux esophagitis retained food in the stomach biopsies negative for H. pylori celiac negative. Colonoscopy showed TI was normal patchy erythema and ulcerations from the cecum to the sigmoid with sigmoid colon being the most active consistent with active colonic Crohn's. Biopsies showed chronic active colitis and dysplasia
-- Saint Luke admission 6/20/2021 for postoperative infection from a tummy tuck in Mexico. Had a postop cellulitis
--GES 7/16/2021 was normal 45% at 1 hour and 1% at 4 hours
--UH admission 1/2024 to 3/2024 spontaneous sepsis arthritis and then went to rehab ICU for 1 month
--Fecal calprotectin 985

Mucosal inflammation changes secondary to Crohn's disease. Likely inflammatory polypoid lesion in the transverse colon. Biopsies of the small bowel ileum showed chronic active inflammation with ulceration. Colon biopsy showed chronic active colitis with mild activity in the polypoid lesion which shows chronic active colitis with ulceration and fibropurulent material.
--MR enterography 2/3/2024 suboptimal distention of the small bowel within these limitations no foci of active inflammation or inflammatory bowel disease complications. No acute or significant abdominal pelvic abnormality.--Colonoscopy

Assessment:
40 year old female we see for colonic crohn's disease, initially diagnosed in 2016 and placed on Budesonide and Lialda at that time. Later placed on Imuran from November 2016-2018. Then sulfasalazine 2019-2020. in May 2020 was started on Stelara but had insurance coverage issues. She was lost to follow up 2021-2024.
Had colonoscopy in January 2024 (with University Health) that did show active disease also biopsies in the TI were positive. Her MRI enterography Jan 2024 of the small bowel was negative but showed suboptimal distention of the small bowel. Repeat MRI November 1, 2024 showed negative MR enterography exam. No current evidence of abnormal wall thickening or active inflammation. No perianal inflammation in the right posterior perianal fistula seen in 2016 has resolved. Was placed back on Lialda 4 pills daily in February 2025.
Currently taking Lialda 4 pills daily. She is having 3-6 bowel movements daily that start off formed and then become mildly loose. She is currently on Enbrel for her joint disease. There has been discussions at past visits about consideration for Skyrizi, however her Rheumatologist mentioned this may not be the best choice since it would not cover her ankylosing spondylitis.  She will continue on Lialda 4 pills daily for now.   We will check a fecal calprotectin as she states she does worry she may have inflammation going on because she has been gaining weight, despite being on Mounjaro (she states weight gain is a symptom of inflammation for her).  Will also check a TSH.  Will have her follow up with Dr. McMyler at next visit to discuss timing of her next colonoscopy for IBD surveillance.
GERD is doing well on pantoprazole 40 mg once daily and famotidine 40 mg once in the evening. She will continue regimen.
Plan:
Fecal calprotectin
TSH with reflex to T4
Follow up with Dr Mcmyler in 4 months

Chief Complaint:
Colitis
History of Present Illness:
Gregory Gordon is a 53 year old  male patient who is seen at the request of Timothy Hernandez for a consultation/initial visit.He presents for evaluation after a recent episode of what is likely an infectious colitis which occurred on an international return flight from Spain. He developed fevers, chills, and nausea, followed by profound diarrhea which is primarily watery and right-sided abdominal pain. After several days of discomfort, he went to a local ER for evaluation and had the workup mentioned below. His symptoms have improved over time and he did complete a 3-day course of therapy with Cipro. He had no hematochezia. There is no history of similar complaints in the past. There were no sick contacts or other obvious exposure while he was traveling. Last colonoscopy was in 2016 and was unremarkable, and he has had imaging studies on several occasions since then which showed no comparable findings.
CT 2016-no acute process
EGD and colonoscopy 2016-class A esophagitis, H. pylori negative gastropathy, otherwise normal including duodenal biopsies, normal colonoscopy with random biopsies
EGD 2021-hiatal hernia, erosive gastropathy and duodenitis
Gastric emptying study 2022-delayed emptying with half emptying time of 208 minutes and mild gastroesophageal reflux
CT 2022-no acute process, diverticulosis, prior ventral hernia repair
Labs 2022-normal CMP, normal hepatic enzymes, normal CBC with platelets, negative celiac serologies, normal TSH, urea breath test negative, ANA positive with a titer of 1-80
ER evaluation 9/2025-multiple benign hepatic cysts, largest 6.3 cm, benign renal cysts measuring up to 4 cm. Pancolitis most severe at the proximal transverse and hepatic flexure region with no dilation with moderate pericolonic inflammatory change with hyperemia and vascular dilation and reactive adenopathy with normal-appearing appendix. White blood cell count 10.7, hematocrit 41, creatinine 0.9, glucose 112, normal hepatic enzymes

Assessment:
Colitis, likely infectious-Differential diagnosis and diagnostic evaluation were discussed. Findings are consistent with a self-limited infectious process, especially given the acuity of onset, association with fevers and chills, absence of other clear etiology based on imaging, and resolution after antibiotic therapy. It is reassuring that previous imaging studies were unremarkable as well. I suspect a self-limited process with no need for further intervention
GERD-Longstanding and associated with a history of mild peptic esophagitis. No consistent therapy at this time is necessary. Recommend upper endoscopy at time of colonoscopy as below.
Screening for colorectal cancer-he is due for screening having last undergone examination in 2016. Options remain broad, but given the nature of recent symptoms I favor colonoscopy. The risks and benefits reviewed and he agrees to proceed
Hepatic cysts- we reviewed that hepatic cysts are commonly identified on routine imaging and that typical imaging modalities such as ultrasound or adequate to make a clear diagnosis and exclude other concerning pathology. we also reviewed that most cysts are asymptomatic and do not require serial imaging because they lack malignant potential. Given the features radiographically, mucinous cystic neoplasm, echinococcal cyst, and other atypical cysts or metastases appear very unlikely. Also, the features of this process are not consistent with polycystic liver based on the cyst number and characteristics. Further therapy is not indicated in this case unless symptoms develop. We discussed potential symptoms associated with hepatic cysts and the patient will contact us if these present themselves.. Otherwise, no further imaging is indicated
Plan:
EGD with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235
Colonoscopy with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia â€“ 45378

incontinenece
History of Present Illness:
Ms. Taylor is a 79 year old patient who presents for a follow up evaluation on constipation and rectal bleeding. She was seen 3/2021 for rectal bleeding, and an atypical lesion was noted, prompting a referral to colorectal surgery for further evaluation. Workup confirmed squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. She has been lost to follow up since 2021. She presents back today at first saying she is doing fine.  Her caregiver says notes that Ms. Taylor has constipation, and often has to strain to have a bowel movement. She can also have some abdominal pain associated with having to have a bowel movement. She has a bowel movement every 2-3 days. She can have bright red blood in the toilet or with wiping sometimes after a bowel movement, but they haven't noticed blood in the stool. She confirms Pantoprazole 40 mg is working well for her GERD. She denies dysphagia or unexplained weight loss. She is still following with oncology, and most recently had chemotherapy November 2022 to January 2023. She has a history of anal squamous cell cancer, though this recurrence was in the groin area.
Patient continues to follow-up with Dr. Luis Rodriguez with most recent office visit in our system in April 2024. CT abdomen pelvis at that time with evidence of cholelithiasis, left upper quadrant diverticulitis, mesenteric twist with severe narrowing versus occlusion of the SMV.

rectal bleeding, hemorroids

Patient being referred for rectal bleeding and history of an external hemorrhoid. She says that she has had hemorrhoids for years and they have involved in her but He in the last 6 months she has been noting blood per rectum. She says that the bleeding happens a few times a week and varies in the amount. She states that she feels like something is blocking the exit of her anus at times making it difficult for her to fully evacuate and having to strain. She says that she has some occasional pain from the hemorrhoid. She has not tried any treatments for it and has not had a rectal exam. She has a bowel movement daily but it is hard to push out. She is on an iron supplement due to a history of iron deficiency anemia from menorrhagia. She says that her stools have become dark since starting on the iron. She had an IUD placed in July and has not had any menstrual bleeding since then. Prior to that she used to have menstrual bleeding for up to a whole month at a time. Her last labs were in June and not available for review. No family history of GI cancers. No prior endoscopy or colonoscopy. No other alarm symptoms. She does report some lower abdominal pain intermittently for the last 6 months rated 6-7 out of 10. No aggravating factors. Heating pad after bowel movement seems to help. Her most recent labs would be available with Dr. Lisa Floris.
