GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease)
Assessment:
Russell is a vigorous 75-year-old black male with history of Raynaud's, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and OSA. He presents today in follow-up) for issues with reflux and recent development of dysphagia. It is certainly suspicious that his dysphagia seemed to occur once he was switched off of PPI and onto famotidine and has had some increased reflux symptoms as well. He did have a barium swallow with his primary care provider which did note concern for mildly delayed transit and tertiary contractions which would certainly be consistent with a reflux induced dysmotility. We discussed options and he prefers to be conservative with trying a different reflux medication. Since he has failed all PPIs available on DOD formulary, will try with low-dose Voquezna and continue with famotidine as well. Should he fail to respond to this it may be reasonable to consider pH impedance and manometry.
Plan:
Voquezna 10 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth, with or without food, once a day, swallow whole,do not chew or crush
Additional Notes:
Thank you for the chance to care for Russell today.

Chief Complaint:
UC
History of Present Illness:
10/22/24-First visit
Christian is a very pleasant otherwise healthy 30-year-old male with a BMI of 24.8 that presents to the office today to see me in consultation from Dr. Friedman with bowel habit changes with mucus in his stools along with hematochezia. Able to review that he has had several years of symptoms however over the last few months worsening for unclear reasons, he describes intermittent occasional loose stools that he feels occurs and "flares", no association with food however occasionally with stressful issues, for the most part he has very soft stools with increased amount of mucus. He has a stable appetite and his weight is unchanged, he denies any fevers or abdominal pain. He has increased amount of rectal bleeding that is more continuous than previous. We did note that he has a remote history in his adolescence of utilizing Accutane for acne. He has no known history of inflammatory bowel disease in his family. He denies any genitourinary symptoms, no ocular changes, no extraintestinal manifestations to suggest inflammatory bowel disease
12/04/24
Christian Gonzales is a 30 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Laboratory studies including IBD panel were negative/normal. Fecal calprotectin 3590. Colonoscopy 11/12/2024 revealed erythema in the cecum, sigmoid colon, and rectum with Mayo score 3 up to 35 cm and biopsies noting active proctitis with mild architectural distortion and surface erosion in the cecum with otherwise normal biopsies.
Patient did start Rowasa enemas every night along with Lialda 4.8 g daily with complete resolution of his symptoms. He is now having 1 bowel movement a day with stools at a 4 on the BSS, and has not had recurrence of rectal bleeding or diarrhea since his procedure. He is tolerating a normal diet. Pt denies abdominal pain, rectal pain, urgency, nocturnal bm, tenesmus, fevers, nausea, vomiting, hematochezia, melena, decreased appetite, or unintentional weight loss.
03/05/25
Christian Gonzales is a 30 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit for UC. Patient has remained on Lialda 4.8 g daily and has actually titrated off of the mesalamine enemas over the last month without recurrence of symptoms. He is having 1-2 bowel movements a day with stools before the BSS. Patient denies rectal pain, hematochezia, nocturnal symptoms, tenesmus, urgency, or abdominal pain. He reports a good appetite, is tolerating a normal diet, and weight has remained stable. Patient also denies nausea, vomiting, fevers, or melena.
06/10/25
Christian Gonzales is a 30 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit for UC. Pt has been able to tolerate decreasing to Liadla 3.6g/day with no increase in BMs. He is having 1-3 bms/day with mostly formed stools around a 5 on the BSS. Patient denies rectal pain, hematochezia, nocturnal symptoms, tenesmus, urgency, or abdominal pain. He reports a good appetite, is tolerating a normal diet, and weight has remained stable. Patient also denies nausea, vomiting, fevers, or melena. Pt does c/o abnormal smell for the last year, which he believes is related to long covid.
07/24/25
Christian Gonzales is a 30 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit for UC. Patient reports sudden onset of symptoms approximately 2 weeks ago where he experienced diarrhea, hematochezia, and abdominal pain. He presented to the ER where his CT did have evidence of active colitis in the rectosigmoid colon with benign labs. He was started on a prednisone taper initially at 40 mg daily. Patient was also recommended to restart mesalamine enemas and Lialda 4.8 g daily over the last 2 weeks. He had slight improvement in symptoms initially, but has now had worsening symptoms of last 3 days. Patient did complete his stool study this past Monday, but we are still waiting on those results. He continues to have 8-10 watery bowel movements a day with hematochezia with every bowel movement. Patient also admits to nocturnal bowel movements, fecal urgency, rectal pain, nausea, lower abdominal cramping, and decreased appetite. He developed a low-grade fever this morning up to 100.2 Â°F. Patient denies vomiting, melena, lightheadedness, dizziness, or syncope.
09/10/25-Today
Christian Gonzales is a 30 year old male who is seen today for a follow-up visit for UC. After our last visit, patient was unfortunately admitted to the hospital due to increase in severity of his symptoms despite remaining on prednisone. During his admission, he did not improve on IV steroids, was thus started on Remicade and completed 2 infusions during that admission. Since then, he has had an additional infusion and was pending another in 6 days. Patient has noted significant improvement in his symptoms since starting Remicade, and also remains on mesalamine 4.8 g daily along with a prednisone taper currently at 15 mg a day and is tapering down 5 mg every week. He is now having 5 bowel movements a day with stools at a 5 on the BSS that are often looser in the morning and become more formed throughout the day. He does continue to have nocturnal bowel movements, but down to once a night rather than several times a night. Patient no longer sees hematochezia and denies tenesmus. However, he does continue to have abdominal cramping predominantly in the left lower quadrant after his bowel movements that is significantly worse in the morning, and alleviated with dicyclomine as needed. Patient also reports occasional rectal pain with defecation. Patient's throat has been slightly dry since his discharge, b and also admits to mild nausea. However, his appetite is back to baseline and is tolerating a normal diet. Patient denies tenesmus, vomiting, fevers, hematochezia, melena, dizziness, or lightheadedness. He does not monitor his weight at home. He has been back to work for the last 2 weeks and doing well.

Assessment:
Christian Gonzalez is a pleasant 30-year-old male who presents to clinic for a flare of ulcerative proctosigmoiditis. Unfortunately, patient was ultimately hospitalized for his flare and during this admission had inductions of Remicade. Since his discharge, patient has noted significant improvement in his symptoms now having 5 bowel movements a day that are loose and formed without hematochezia. However, he continues to have nocturnal bowel movements and abdominal cramping. Considering his symptoms have significantly improved, I do recommend that he continue on his current medical course with the Remicade infusions, mesalamine 4.8 g daily, and complete the prednisone taper as directed as it will likely take additional time to induce complete remission. I also encouraged patient to continue supportive measures including avoid NSAIDs and utilize dicyclomine/Tylenol as needed for cramping. Strict ER/return precautions were discussed. We will also repeat laboratory studies at this time for surveillance. Patient expressed understanding and agreed with plan.
Plan:
Complete Blood Count (CBC) with Diff
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP)
C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)
Follow-up office visit in 4-6 weeks
Continue current medications
Additional Notes:
Thank you, Dr. Friedman, for the opportunity care for Mr. Gonzalez

Assessment:
34 year-old male with a history of H. pylori infection (2022, confirmed eradication by breath test 6/2025), gallbladder polyps, prediabetes, hypercholesteremia, asthma presents for evaluation of liver lesions.
1. Liver enzyme elevation: He has a history of chronic hepatocellular elevation in the last 3 years. He denies IVDU, blood transfusion, alcohol use, tattoo, or a family history of liver disease. He drinks herbal and green tea.
- Arrange for blood work to elucidate the etiology of liver enzyme elevation.
- Arrange for liver elastography to evaluate for fibrosis. If elevated, consider liver biopsy as the next step.
2. Liver lesion: Recent ultrasound revealed an incidental finding of a liver lesion, suggestive of hemangioma. MRI is already arranged on 9/24/25 by Dr. Kromann Martin (PCP).
- Follow up the liver MRI for further characterization.
3. Gallbladder polyp: He has a history of gallbladder polyp dating back 5 years, previously reportedly 4 mm in size. Ultrasound this year (done in China) revealed an incidental finding of a 6 mm gallbladder polyp.
The size difference could be related to where the imaging was performed and operator dependent.
- Arrange for ultrasound abdomen.
Plan:
Ultrasound abdomen with elastography of the liver, for surveillance of gallbladder polyp and elastography of the liver in the setting of abnormal liver enzyme elevation

Thank you so much for referring your patient for an initial gastroenterology consultation. History was obtained from the patient and father. The patient had a history of constipation since infancy, with symptoms worsening over the past couple of years. The patient had been on and off MiraLAX to manage constipation, which exacerbates when not on the medication. Even when on MiraLAX, the patient hesitated to use the bathroom and experienced occasional accidents. The patient did not report abdominal pain but had episodes of stool leakage. The patient had been on the current dose of MiraLAX for about two weeks, following previous cycles over the past four years. No significant weight gain or growth concerns were noted, though the patient had always been on the smaller side. The patient was slow to talk and walk during early development. There were no known food allergies or special diet requirements. The patient consumed a limited diet with insufficient fruits and vegetables and no known avoidance of specific food proteins.

Diagnoses:
Constipation, slow transit
Encopresis
Assessment:
1. Chronic Constipation: The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms, given the long-standing history and response to MiraLAX. Despite the use of MiraLAX, the patient continued to experience issues, suggesting possible inadequate bowel clearance or dietary insufficiencies.
2. Dietary Insufficiencies: The patient's limited intake of fiber from fruits and vegetables might contribute to the constipation, as fiber is crucial in maintaining regular bowel movements.
3. Possible Underlying Condition: Consideration for underlying conditions such as celiac disease or thyroid dysfunction due to family history and prolonged symptoms. Blood tests were planned to rule out these possibilities.
PLAN:
Treatment:
- Continued MiraLAX: half a capful daily
- Encouraged increased water intake to 24 ounces daily
- Recommended increasing dietary fiber with three servings of fruits and vegetables daily
Tests:
- Blood work to screen for celiac disease, thyroid function, and check electrolytes
- Abdominal X-ray to assess for fecal impaction
Patient Education:
- Discussed importance of fiber and hydration in managing constipation
- Encouraged presenting foods in a manner acceptable to the patient to increase intake
Follow-Up:
- Planned follow-up appointment after test results to evaluate effectiveness of interventions and further management
Plan:
Complete Blood Count (CBC) with Diff
C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP)
Celiac Ab profile: tTg IgG/IgA, DGP IgG/IgA, total IgA
TSH with reflex to T4
Abdomen X-ray 1 view (KUB) - 74018
Additional Notes:
stat xray to be read by peds radiology.  Goal is 24 ounces of water and 3 servings of a combination of fruits/veggies daily.

Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Discussed anti-reflux measures
Do not eat 3 hours before laying down.
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)
Recommend lifestyle modifications- low fat diet, avoid alcohol consumption, and exercise 30 minutes per day, with a goal of 5x/weekly.
Follow-up in office two weeks after procedure
Obtain Cardiac clearance for planned procedure
Hold Ozempic (semaglutide) for 7 days prior to procedure.
Do not stop taking aspirin for the procedure.
On the procedure day take your usual morning blood pressure/heart medications with liquids at least 4 hours before procedure

Chief Complaint:
trouble swallowing, choking, discuss EGD with dilation
History of Present Illness:
Lisa Bonvillain is a 65 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit with EGD/Colonoscopy 12/15/2023 and follow up barium enema 12/20/2023 - reviewed with patient today. She presents today at request of Dr Robichaux due to complaints of mid chest pain and dysphagia where she describes meats, especially red meats and chicken, can sit in her mid chest and will take a while to go down. This has been occurring for the past several months and she denies ever having this before. She has more long term issues with swallowing pills and has to be careful but this has not been progressive. Denies history of GERD but has recently started pantoprazole with PCP 09/10/2025 and has not had symptoms since starting this. Denies nausea, vomiting, true abdominal pain (although she does report tenderness to epigastric abdomen with palpation). She has intermittent bloating, belching, and flatulence which has been a long term thing for her but feels belching is increasing. History of alternating bowel habits of constipation, diarrhea, and normal stools in between. She can go 2-3 days without a bowel movement and then when she has a bowel movement she can have hard rocky stools, normal stools, and diarrhea. She feels constipation and diarrhea can occur equally. She does not take anything for either of these nor does she care to. She is on probiotics x 2 years which does not help much. She is on slow mag for leg cramps and does not feel this helps bowels at all. Denies fecal incontinence but admits to intermittent history of this. Denies nocturnal stooling, overt GI bleeding, or unexplained weight loss. History of partial hysterectomy (still has her ovaries) and bladder lift 17-18 years ago. She has intermittent urinary leakage. No response to pelvic floor therapy. She has previously followed Dr Knoeppe but has not seen her since 2022. Chief Complaint:
post colonoscopy
History of Present Illness:
Deborah Robichaux is a 80 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit. Last visit with Colonoscopy  8/19/2025 with biopsies revealing collagenous colitis. Post procedure she started budesonide 2 daily but due to concern for side effects she decreased to daily dosing but with this she had recent flare so she increased back to 2 daily with resolution of diarrhea. She has previously been on colestipol 2 daily which she increased to 4 daily (with PCP) right before colonoscopy and continues on daily probiotics. She is no longer on librax, she did not feel she tolerated dicyclomine. She has done Imodium, lomotil. She took course of xifaxin prior to Colon which helped some too. She is currently having 1-2 bowel movements a day, and on occasion she can go a day without a bowel movement, with most stools being formed and soft. Denies overt GI bleeding, acholic stools. She has occasional bloating and abdominal cramping which is relieved with defecation. Denies nocturnal stooling, fever or mucous in stools. Denies dysphagia, vomiting, GERD symptoms. She continues to have vague intermittent nausea which remains unchanged. She is down 10 pounds from 6/2025 but this is stable now and she reports making recent diet changes. Hx of smoking but no longer smokes. Denies alcohol use. She is on diclofenac for shoulder pain. She has shoulder/balance issues and is following PT. Denies statin use. She remains on betablocker. She has been on SSRIs but not recently. Cologuard 2024, Remote history of EGD and gastric ulcer - she continues to want to hold off of repeat EGD as well as repeat CT at this time.

Chief Complaint:
Follow Up
History of Present Illness:
This is a 66-year-old male presenting for a follow-up visit for liver cirrhosis, iron deficiency anemia, and hepatitis B core antibody positive status. This is a follow-up from a visit in April. The purpose of this visit is to review recent investigations and monitor his conditions. He reports feeling better and his anemia has resolved. He denies seeing any blood in his stool. He has a history of bullous skin lesions, for which he was previously on Rituxan, but this was discontinued approximately one year ago. He also has a history of hiatal hernia and a tortuous esophagus. He has been abstinent from alcohol for four years.
Prior Tests Reviewed:
- An ultrasound of the liver performed in May at HCA hospital showed no evidence of liver cancer or gallstones. It did note a possible kidney stone, which is not of clinical significance.
- Blood work from May was reviewed. Liver function tests show a slightly elevated AST of 42 and alkaline phosphatase of 206, with other liver numbers being within normal limits. INR is 1.2. Platelet count is 316,000, which is a good number for an individual with cirrhosis.
- The alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) cancer marker was 1.2, which is well below the concerning threshold of 6.
- Hepatitis B DNA is not detectable.
- A prior upper endoscopy from 2022 showed a hiatal hernia and a tortuous esophagus, but no esophageal varices.
- A colonoscopy performed at the same time as the 2022 EGD had a suboptimal prep but was otherwise unremarkable.
4/29/2025 Patient is here for routine follow up after 6 months. He remains wheelchair bound and overall deconditioned with associated weight loss. Since last visit, he was hospitalized for pneumonia and was discharged for SNF, where he received inpatient rehab. He is currently receiving home health services for PT/OT. He has not seen his dermatologist in over 6 months and has not received Rituxan infusion in 1 year. He is no longer on chronic steroids and reports that his bullous pemphigoid is in remission. I counseled that he can stop tenofovir. He is overdue for labs and liver imaging, which I will order today. Of note, he has not been taking pantoprazole at home, which I will refill today. He was recently started on Plavix for "bad circulation in legs" a couple of months ago. Will try to call his sister next week to confirm name of vascular surgeon to discuss indication for Plavix. He is high risk for GI bleeding given recurrent esophagitis and ulcers with associated bleeding. He is overdue for EGD for variceal screening, but he is deferring this for now given his insurance is out of network with all of the hospitals that I offer endoscopy.
10/7/2024 This is a telehealth appointment conducted from my office at 11920 Astoria Blvd Suite 410 Houston, TX 77089 using audio connection only. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow up appointment. Patient unfortunately suffered from a fall onto his R shoulder and hip and has since had pain in his R leg preventing him from walking. He has been using a wheelchair for his mobility needs. He presented to ER acutely after fall, and all of his x-rays were negative at the time. He has repeat scans later this month with his PCP given ongoing pain and weakness. He has not followed up with dermatologist since we last spoke with him. I spoke with his dermatology PA 2 weeks ago, who said patient would likely need another dose of Rituxan for his bullous pemphigoid but has been lost to follow up. He has apparently been refilling his steroids but patient denies taking steroids and reports that his skin is currently clear. I recommended following up with dermatology when he can to be reassessed for another round of Rituxan. He remains on HBV prophylaxis daily and is tolerating medication well. He is taking ibuprofen daily for his leg pain, which I recommended he stop given his history of IDA and GI bleeding. He will take low dose Tylenol PRN instead and discuss pain management strategies with his PCP. His is due for HCC surveillance. Patient has poor health literacy and poor social support, and he is now wheelchair bound, which has contributed to poor follow up with his specialists.
07/01/2024 This is a follow up appointment. Patient was started on Rituxan for his bullous pemphigoid in 04/24. He was started on Viread at the same time for HBV prophylaxis due to findings of HBcAb+ indicating prior exposure or prior HBV infection. He stopped taking Viread temporarily in 05/24 due to concern for it possibly causing joint pain but the restarted medication without side effects later in 05/24 and is tolerating well. He had follow up with his dermatologist in 06/24 and noted that he does not have any plans for upcoming Rituxan infusions. He remains on methylprednisone 4mg QD and is taking PPI QD for GI prophylaxis. Recent labs showed slightly elevated LFTs but normal AFP and no significant anemia. His weight is stable at 170lbs. He is due for variceal screening but wishes to hold off given facility is out of network and stable clinical status. He will be due for liver imaging in 09/24, which I will order today. He will need to be on HBV prophylaxis x 6 months after completing Rituxan.
03/19/2024 He is here for follow-up. Denies any nausea vomiting hematemesis or melena. He remains on treatment with steroids for bullous pemphigoid, plans to start an infusion treatment with his dermatologist soon. He is due for an upper endoscopy but his local hospital is out of network and he wishes to wait until it becomes a lot worse.
1/9/2024 Patient is here for follow up after 3 months. Patient has gained 20lbs since last office visit, which he attributes to increased appetite. Denies swelling in legs, hands, or stomach. Denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. He remains on lactulose, which keeps his stools regular. Denies visible GI bleeding. Labs in 12/23 with  AST 61, ALT 110, WBC 11.4. He is due for liver imaging, which I will order today. He will also be due for EGD for variceal screening in a couple of months, which I will order today. He reports a new diffuse rash on his trunk that is pruritic and looks different from his bullous pemphigoid. His dermatologist is working up the rash currently. He remains on methylprednisone daily.
10/9/23 This is a telehealth appointment conducted from my office at 11920 Astoria Blvd Suite 410 Houston, TX using audio connection only. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow up visit. Labs in 06/23 with AST 41, ALT 60, which are increased from previous panel. Patient denies drinking for last 6 months. Ultrasound of liver in 07/23 with no masses or evidence of HCC. Today, he reports feeling well. He denies abdominal pain, nausea, constipation, diarrhea, visible edema, visible GI bleeding. He remains on PPI daily for reflux with relief of symptoms. He also remains on methylprednisone 4mg QD for bullous pemphigoid. He is requesting refill of lactulose, which I will send today. 6/27/2023 He is here for routine follow-up. Reflux is under control. He remains on steroids for bullous pemphigoid condition. He is requesting a refill for proton pump inhibitor and lactulose.
10/11/2022 He is here for follow-up. He states that he stopped drinking alcohol as of 3 months. No recent labs. He had abnormal liver function tests in June but he was also actively drinking at that time. He is due for repeat labs and ultrasound for hepatocellular carcinoma screening
06/14/2022 He is here for follow-up. Recommended avoiding NSAIDs.

02/07/2022 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using audio only communication since video is unavailable. He remains on PPI twice daily as instructed. He has stopped NSAID use as well but remains on methylprednisolone from his dermatologist. Discussed recommendations for repeat EGD given gastric ulcers and intestinal metaplasia on biopsies. He is also overdue for colonoscopy given poor prep in 2017. 11/30/2021 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office (11920 Astoria Blvd, St 410, Houston 77089) using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. His sister was also present on the call. This is a procedure follow-up after recent EGD. We discussed procedure findings in detail including multiple antral ulcers, 7 cm x 7 cm hiatal hernia, and GE junction stenosis which was dilated to 20 mm. Interestingly, he denies any dysphagia before or after procedure. Biopsies were negative for malignancy and showed chronic active gastritis with intestinal metaplasia. We discussed the potential precancerous nature of these findings especially in light of ulcers and chronic gastritis. I recommended repeat EGD in 3 to 6 months and continue PPI bid in the meantime. I also recommended NSAID avoidance including meloxicam. Patient is currently being weaned off methylprednisolone which was prescribed by his dermatologist.
08/09/2021 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using bidirectional synchronous video communication tool. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. He is coming up due for an upper endoscopy for surveillance for both gastric ulcers, esophageal varices and large hiatal hernia which will be scheduled later this year. Risks and benefits of the procedure were discussed in detail.
05/06/2021 This is a telehealth visit being conducted at the request of patient from my office using audio connection. Appropriate informed consent was obtained. This is a follow-up visit. 11/26/2019 He is here with his sister for procedure follow up. Reviewed recent EGD results including moderate gastritis, erosive duodenitis, large hiatal herania, and bile reflux gastritis. 07/30/2019 He is here after over a year. Since the last visit he has been admitted to the hospital in July 2018 with acute alcohol intoxication. He has admitted himself to outpatient alcohol rehab program and is currently sober for the last 3 months. Assessment:
1. Liver Cirrhosis, stable - K74.60
- The cirrhosis appears to be stable with good synthetic function, as evidenced by the normal INR and good platelet count. The surveillance ultrasound and AFP are reassuring and negative for hepatocellular carcinoma.
- Plan is for continued monitoring.
- Will continue six-monthly follow-up appointments.
2. Hepatitis B core antibody positive - Z22.51
- The patient's hepatitis B DNA is undetectable. He was previously on tenofovir (Viread) for prophylaxis while on Rituxan for his skin condition.
- Given that the Rituxan was stopped approximately one year ago, the tenofovir is no longer medically necessary.
- Instructed to discontinue tenofovir.
3. Esophageal varices screening - Z13.818
- The last upper endoscopy was in 2022, and it is recommended to repeat this for screening of esophageal varices, which are a known complication of cirrhosis.
- An upper endoscopy will be ordered to screen for varices and evaluate his known hiatal hernia and reflux symptoms. The procedure will be scheduled at the Pearland Surgery Center due to insurance constraints with Memorial Hermann. Staff will assist with scheduling.
4. Medication Refills - Z76.0
- Refill for lactulose was sent to CVS pharmacy as requested.
- A prescription for pantoprazole for acid reduction was also sent to CVS pharmacy.

Chief Complaint:
liver thrombus f/u
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 71-year-old male with past medical history significant for NASH, CAD, diabetes, HLD, HTN, OSA on CPAP recent diagnosis of SMV thrombus who presents to clinic today for follow-up.
Patient was admitted to the ICU at Baylor Irving, followed by Dr. Mahatma, for SMV thrombosis with extension to the mesenteric veins and portal vein along with mesenteric edema. There is questionable evidence of nodular contoured appearance of liver on prior CT abdomen and pelvis, but no such appearance on most recent CT scan and no other evidence of cirrhosis. There was mention of ischemic enteritis secondary to mesenteric and portal vein thrombosis. Thus far, cirrhosis and viral/autoimmune workup negative. Suspected to likely have underlying steatohepatitis. Patient currently follows with hematologist, Dr. Juvvadi, who is following the patient while on Eliquis. While inpatient surgery and IR was consulted and recommended placement of thrombolysis catheter. Repeat on 6/25 showed persistent SMV thrombosis and was recommended to continue thrombolysis for additional 24 hours. Patient with no GI complaints at this time, denies any melena, hematochezia, unintentional weight loss, loss of appetite reflux or dysphagia.
Most recent labs show BUN 14, creatinine 0.9, ALP 102, AST 25, ALT 23, bilirubin 1.0, H&H 13.1/40.9, MCV 91.9, platelet count 188,000, PT/INR 13.0/1.1. Negative CEA/CA 19.9.
Patient has upcoming appointment with hematology this week. Plan is to continue Eliquis indefinitely for now. Patient reports that he was diagnosed with factor II deficiency on hematologic workup. Inciting event for original clot, believed to be related to IVIG infusion. Patient had started IVIG infusions for an undisclosed immunodeficiency, but was only able to receive 1 infusion until he was hospitalized for his SMV thrombosis.

Chief Complaint:
diarrhea
History of Present Illness:
Constance Ginn is a 71 year old  female patient who is seen at the request of Vipulkumar Patel for a consultation/initial visit.
Patient presents today for follow-up of chronic diarrhea, which has been ongoing for many years (patient states 'over twenty years'). Reports experiencing diarrhea 2-3 times per week, with occasional episodes of fecal urgency and incontinence. Patient describes a recent incident where they had an accident while moving from the couch to the bathroom. The diarrhea appears to be random but often occurs in the morning. Patient expresses concern about leaving home due to fear of having accidents in public. Denies blood in stool, weight loss, or trouble swallowing. Patient reports feeling otherwise healthy but notes significant impact on quality of life due to symptoms.
Patient has a history of microscopic lymphocytic colitis diagnosed on previous biopsies. Has previously been treated with medications including Valsalamine and Budesonide (Entocort) with good response. Patient reports that previous medication regimen had completely resolved symptoms and allowed them to feel 'secure about going out.' Currently using Pepto-Bismol with some relief.
Patient also has a history of MS, diagnosed approximately 10 years ago, and is followed by Dr. Patel (PCP) and a neurologist. Denies current significant life stressors or anxiety.
Review of Medical Records:
- Previous diagnosis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) reported in the past, though Prometheus testing was not consistent with IBD
- Previous biopsy confirmed lymphocytic colitis (microscopic colitis)
- Prior treatments included cholestyramine, Budesonide, and Valsalamine in 2015
- Records indicate complete resolution of diarrhea with previous medication regimen
- Comorbid conditions include MS and hypercholesterolemia

Assessment:
I have reviewed available records and discussed them with patient. We have discussed current clinical scenario and the differential diagnosis.
1. Microscopic Lymphocytic Colitis with chronic diarrhea
- Patient with long-standing history of microscopic colitis with current symptomatic relapse
- Symptoms significantly impacting quality of life with fear of leaving home due to urgency and occasional incontinence
- Plan for colonoscopy with biopsies to reassess disease status and confirm diagnosis
- In the interim, recommended over-the-counter management with Imodium and/or Pepto-Bismol as needed
- Will consider restarting previous effective medication regimen (likely Budesonide) after confirmation of diagnosis
- Discussed newer medication options that may be available depending on colonoscopy findings
2. Multiple Sclerosis
- Currently managed by neurology
- No acute neurological complaints today
- Continue current management with neurologist
Plan:
My office will obtain prior lab results
TTG IgA/IgG (No LabCorp)

Chief Complaint:
Gastritis
History of Present Illness:
Sam is a very pleasant 43-year-old male with BMI of 25 presents to the office today to see me in consultation from Dr. Kundur, accompanied by his father with noncardiac chest pain. He has had a previous history of similar, had an endoscopy done over 5 years ago for similar situations that presented with dysphagia and chest discomfort with regurgitation, endoscopically with benign esophageal stricture treated with therapeutic dilation at the time and he had done well on PPI therapy. He does have poor dietary habits stemming from his opportunity where he works for unlimited soda and his mental delay and cognitive issues. In early August on the eighth and 2025 he was exhibiting very similar symptoms and his father took him to the emergency department, cardiac etiology was ruled out and a suspected recurrent gastritis. Given a prescription for Prilosec that has markedly improved but not completely eliminated his symptoms. He denies any solid or liquid dysphagia but does have some occasional nausea and vomiting and regurgitation. Weight is stable

Nausea with vomiting (e)
Regurgitation of food (c)
Assessment:
43-year-old male with a BMI of 25 with a previous history of hiatal hernia with esophageal stricture and esophagitis, history of long-term but stable mental retardation with significant dietary indiscretions as a behavioral habit that had induced symptoms in the past of bloating and intermittent abdominal discomfort along with noncardiac chest pain. Recent evaluation a month ago in the emergency department shows no cardiac etiology, some improvement but not at all completely resolving his symptoms with PPI therapy. Strongly discussed with patient and his father the importance of dietary modification and limiting soda and junk food, continue with PPI therapy and based upon his presentation I think it reasonable to evaluate with endoscopy to see if the stricture has reformed that he is feeling as regurgitation with nausea and vomiting
Plan:
Lose weight with diet/exercise as discussed. Attempt 10% body weight loss over 6 months.*
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Continue current medications
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) - 43235

Ms Esley is a 83-year-old female who presents for new evaluation for constipation and abdominal pain. Was seen at Christus Santa Rosa ER 8/24/2025 and showed constipation and was given Bentyl On MiraLaxIs here today with her husband. Was given Bentyl in the ER but never tried it however she did take get a dose of it in the ER and it helped her pain.
Has history of diverticulitis in the past and was diagnosed in September 2017. Also has a history of an IPMN. Does have family history of her dad having pancreatic cancer.Patient states has been having lower abdominal pain that she describes as abdominal cramping and usually suprapubic. Usually occurs 3 hours after eating usually after her biggest meal which is dinner. Will eat around 4 or 5 and then will have cramping around 7 PM. Takes 2 ibuprofen when she has the pain and her pain then will resolve. Does not have as many symptoms when she eats a smaller meal such as cereal. Chief Complaint:
4 week follow up ER follow up; Upper GI bleed
History of Present Illness:
7/1/2025. Dr. Pearce.
Barbara presents with abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits that have been ongoing for several months. She has a history of breast cancer and is followed by an oncologist.
The patient reports experiencing pain in her lower abdomen, which has been accompanied by alternating constipation and diarrhea. The constipation is currently more frequent, though she did have a bowel movement on the day of the visit. Barbara describes the onset of her symptoms as starting a couple of months ago with gas pains. She denies any known triggers for her symptoms and has not noticed any blood in her stool. The patient mentions that she doesn't "go like [she] should," indicating a change in her normal bowel habits.
Barbara has not sought medical attention specifically for these symptoms prior to this visit, though she did mention them to her nephrologist, who suggested she see a gastroenterologist. She reports having regular CT scans every 3-4 months as part of her oncology follow-up. The patient recalls being told she had diverticulitis, though it's unclear if this was confirmed by imaging. She denies significant weight loss, stating she has been trying to lose a little weight but nothing major.
The patient's symptoms appear to be impacting her daily life, prompting her to seek medical attention. She is currently taking a daily baby aspirin but denies being on any blood thinners.
Medical History
- Breast cancer, under oncological care with regular CT scans every 3-4 months
- Diverticulitis, diagnosed earlier this year
- Kidney condition, under care of a nephrologist
Surgical History
- Colonoscopy in 2023
Medications and Supplements
- Baby aspirin
- Taken daily

9/11/2025. NP Durand.
Barbara Henk is a 76 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit.
Patient was hospitalized 2 months ago for hematochezia. Inpatient colonoscopy revealed bleeding AVM or dieulafoy lesion in proximal transverse colon, now s/p bipolar cautery, moderate benign-appearing stenosis in sigmoid colon, likely due to diverticular disease, and multiple nonbleeding diverticula in descending colon and sigmoid colon, and internal hemorrhoids. Prior colonoscopy done by Dr. Hays Arnold in San Antonio 9/2023 revealed severe sigmoid diverticulosis and grade 3 internal hemorrhoids.
Today she reports taking omeprazole once daily and reports mo reflux symptoms. She reports daily, sometimes every other day, bowel movements of soft stools, occasionally formed stools. She admits to inadequate dietary fiber intake but endorses adequate water intake. She reports abdominal bloating and gassiness if she skips a day without having a bowel movement. She denies hematochezia or melena, or other upper or lower GI symptoms currently.

Assessment:
Patient with history of GERD with recent hospitalization for GI bleed diagnosed with transverse colon AVM, diverticulosis and internal hemorrhoids on inpatient colonoscopy. Hematochezia resolved since hospitalization and bipolar cautery of AVM. Recommend continue omeprazole 40 mg daily. Recommend high-fiber diet, including fiber supplementation with Benefiber starting with 1 teaspoon of fluids daily, and adequate hydration to achieve daily soft bowel movements. Monitor symptoms and report back to office or ER if recurrence of symptoms. Further screening/surveillance colonoscopy optional based on age/condition of patient.
Plan:
Continue current medications
Continue with current treatment plan
Continue current Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI) as instructed.
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)

Chief Complaint:
IBS
History of Present Illness:
3/18/2024
Cecelia is a very pleasant 76-year-old female that presents to the office today to see me for evaluation of abdominal pain with constipation. Able to review that pain has been present for some time, she has significant constipation, she will go as long as 7 to 8 days without having a spontaneous bowel movement. She has been tried on several different medications without any overt improvement now utilizing Linzess 290 mcg along with stool softeners daily. This has improved the bowel movements to once every 4 to 7 days. She states that over time this causes significant left lower and left upper quadrant abdominal pressure and discomfort. She states that over 10 years ago she underwent a repair which appears to be a rectocele and cystocele repair that developed into some inadvertent misadventures that required additional surgical intervention. I do not have any of these records however she indicates that since that time she has had difficulty with urination as well as constipation. Last colonoscopy was in 2016, she does not remember any findings told to her at that time. She describes some perineal esthesia in that region as well following the surgery. Unfortunately she has a significant retinal hemorrhage which is being managed conservatively at this time by ophthalmology, there is a concern and fear that she may lose eyesight in 1 or both eyes potentially. Along with this last week she underwent a cardiac catheterization by her report for which she was noted to have 90% and 75% proximal large vessel occlusion however after intraprocedural consultation with her ophthalmologist they decided against antiplatelet therapy given the concern for advancing the retinal hemorrhage and complete blindness. She denies any melena or hematochezia, no vomiting but occasional nausea.
7/11/2024
Cecelia is a very pleasant 76-year-old female with a BMI of 24 that returns to the office today to see me in follow-up. We were able to review that since our last visit in consultation she has undergone cardiac stenting, dealing with issues with her blood pressure. Intermittent with this she has had some nausea, bowel movements have somewhat improved with utilizing Linzess, able to review also that sitz marker study is normal. She does describe some bilateral upper left and right rib pain as well as in the midepigastric region, by report ultrasound of the abdomen showed no abnormalities, she describes this pain as somewhat constant, worse with body position and bending over as well as exertion, she continues to work with her cardiologist regarding the symptoms as well. She denies any solid or liquid dysphagia, no weight changes.
02/05/25
Cecelia Garcia is a 76 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for constipation. Last visit 7/11/2024 patient seen for IBS, constipation, GERD, and epigastric abdominal pain with recommendation to start MiraLAX, Citrucel, and pantoprazole 40 mg as well as remain on Linzess 290 mcg.
Patient presents today complaining of worsening abdominal pain associated with unintentional weight loss of approximately 20 pounds in the last 2 months. She reports epigastric abdominal pain that is sharp, radiating to the right lower quadrant, and constant without any known alleviating factors. She does state that it can be worse with p.o. intake, which has resulted in some decreased appetite. She has tried to utilize hot packs, ice compresses, and Tylenol without any significant improvement. Patient reports associated nausea, dry heaving, and headaches. She is utilizing omeprazole 40mg q day. Her bowel habits are still slightly improved utilizing Linzess 145 mcg once daily as she is having 2 bowel movements a week with stools at a 7 on the BSS. She also utilizes senna as needed that does allow her to evacuate fully. Patient denies melena, hematochezia, fevers, vomiting, dysphagia, odynophagia, pyrosis, or indigestion. She has been off of Plavix since November. However, she still has a history of severe CAD with 90% and 75% proximal large vessel occlusion.
04/07/25
Cecelia Garcia is a 77 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for abdominal pain, constipation, and GERD. CT 02/10/2025 negative for acute intra-abdominal processes. EGD 3/14/2025 was normal with normal biopsies.
Patient continues to complain of epigastric pain, but is improved now occurring intermittently rather than constant. The pain does occur on a daily basis, is sharp or pressure-like in quality, associated with nausea, and often occurs after p.o. intake or even in the middle of the night that can awaken her from sleep, but will alleviate after evacuation. Additionally, she reports new onset of constant RLQ pain over the last week that is associated with increased urination and incontinence. She does report momentary relief of pain with IBgard and/or dicyclomine as needed. "Patient did not start famotidine as previously prescribed, but remains on omeprazole 20 mg twice daily. She denies any conventional reflux symptoms, her appetite is back to baseline, any she has been able to regain 5 pounds since her last visit. As for her bowel habits, she continues to have uncontrolled constipation despite remaining on Linzess 145 mcg daily and Metamucil. She is having 3-4 bowel movements every 3 days at a 6 on the BSS, but without complete emptying. Pt denies hematochezia, melena, dysuria, hematuria, pyrosis, indigestion, vomiting, fevers, dysphagia, decreased appetite,  and unintentional weight loss
07/09/25
Cecelia Garcia is a 77 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for abdominal pain, constipation, and GERD. Patient continues to report intermittent epigastric pain that does occur on a daily basis and is sharp or pressure-like in quality, associated with nausea, and often occurs after p.o. intake or in the middle of the night that can awaken her from sleep. Her pain can be alleviated with evacuation with the use of a hot pack. As per her bowel habits, she continues to have uncontrolled constipation as she has been unable to tolerate Linzess 145 mcg daily due to side effects of significant diarrhea. Therefore, she is currently utilizing Linzess every other day or every few days along with MiraLAX and Metamucil 3 times a week. Patient is also utilizing a stimulant laxative as needed. Patient is currently having 1 bowel movement every 3 to 4 days with hard and loose. Patient states she also had to discontinue omeprazole as it had been causing her short-term memory loss, but does remain on famotidine 20 mg twice daily without control of symptoms. She reports brash taste in mouth and pyrosis almost every evening. Patient denies hematochezia, melena, vomiting, dysphagia, decreased appetite, or unintentional weight loss. Her weight has been stable since her last visit and appetite has been at baseline.
09/10/25-Today
Cecelia Garcia is a 77 year old female who is seen today for a follow-up visit for abdominal pain, constipation, and GERD. Pt has been taking lubiprostone 8mcg BID along with metamucil daily\ and Linzess 145mcg prn. She is having a bowel movement every 4 days only after taking linzess, and has stools that are typically soft. She had f/u with her PCP on Monday who reportedly started several new medications including 2 for constipation, one of which is lactulose, but she is unsure of the other name. Pt has not yet obtained either medication. She continues to c/o nausea, bloating, and abdominal cramping.  Patient again reports intermittent epigastric pain that does occur on a daily basis and is sharp or pressure-like in quality, which does alleviate with her hot pack. She also had an instance of RLQ discomfort when she was constipated, which has resolved. She is drinking about 4 water bottles daily and tries to have fiber though is only having 1 meal a day. Pt is taking pantoprazole 40mg q day, famotidine 40mg prn about 3 times a week at night, and gaviscon qhs. Pt still has pyrosis about once a day typically in the evening, which is alleviated gaviscon prn. Pt denies vomiting, melena, hematochezia, dysphagia, or unintentional weight loss. She reports decreased appetite, but weight is stable. Pt takes several OTC vitamins (multi, b complex, and biotin), which she does not take with meals.

IBS (irritable bowel syndrome)
Constipation
GERD (gastroesophageal reflux disease)
Assessment:
Cecelia Garcia is a pleasant 77-year-old female with a past medical history of constipation, GERD, CAD, HLD, HTN, migraines, sleep apnea, and fibromyalgia who presents to clinic for a follow up on abdominal pain, nausea, constipation, and GERD. Patient continues to report intermittent epigastric pain associated with uncontrolled constipation, nausea, pyrosis, and brash taste in mouth. She did not have any significant improvement on lubiprostone 8mcg BID, and had f/u with her PCP who reportedly sent in 2 additional medications including lactulose for her to add to her bowel regimen, but is unsure of the name of the new med other than lactulose. I will request records for review. She denies alarm features, weight is stable, and had recent EGD and CT that have been benign. I continue to suspect her abdominal pain and possibly even her increased GERD is related to her poorly controlled constipation. Therefore, I do recommend she trial the lactulose as prescribed by her PCP, and continue on lubiprostone 8mcg BID along with adequate hydration and exercise as tolerated. As for her GERD, I recommended she continue on pantoprazole 40 mg daily along with famotidine 40 mg nightly and adhere to aggressive antireflux measures as well as utilize ondansetron as needed. If her symptoms persist despite better control of her bowel habits and reflux, then we may consider further evaluation with include possible CT angiography. Patient expressed understanding and agreed with plan.
Plan:
My office will obtain records from referring physician, most recent OV
Adhere to lifestyle and dietary modifications for GERD diet as we discussed. This includes avoiding fatty and greasy foods, fried foods, tomato based foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, coffee and alcohol. Elevate the head of your bed 6 inches. Additionally, do not eat or drink anything including water within two hours of going to bed at night or 10pm, whichever comes first. Recommend low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise.
Avoid NSAIDs (Motrin, Advil, ibuprofen, Aleve, Naproxen, etc.)
Follow-up office visit in 6-8 weeks
Additional Notes:
Thank you for the opportunity to care for Ms. Garcia

Assessment:
78-year-old female presents to gastroenterology clinic with 2-month history of diarrhea. She will have anywhere from 4-6 bowel movements per day, occasionally incontinence. No overt GI bleeding, melena, hematochezia. She will have a left upper quadrant discomfort and occasional nausea. She has chronically been iron deficient given that she has a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass which was performed in 2004. Approximately 2 years ago, it sounds like she may have had a small bowel obstruction from adhesions requiring further intervention. She has a history of pancreatic cysts noted first in 2021 and followed by MRI every year. Latest MRI 8/8/2024 with a 12 mm tubular cystic lesion contiguous with the main pancreatic duct, smaller 5 mm cyst in the tail. The pancreatic cyst was 10 mm in 2023.
I would like to check stool studies to evaluate for infection, elastase to evaluate for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. She should be on a low FODMAP diet, probiotic, Lomotil. Will plan for colonoscopy with segmental biopsy. Given her left upper quadrant discomfort and nausea, we will pursue EGD to evaluate her anatomy. Will be looking for strictures, stenosis, anastomotic ulcerations. Will take biopsies of the jejunum. Will plan for an MRI, MRCP to evaluate for pancreatic cyst. She should continue to follow with hematology for routine blood work and transfusions as necessary.
Plan:
Gastrointestinal Pathogen / GPP (QDx and Genesis)
Fecal elastase
Low FODMAP diet
Low FODMAP diet extensive, patient education materials generated by EMR
Use probiotics as instructed.
Lomotil 2.5-0.025 mg Take 1 tablet by mouth three times a day as needed for diarrhea

Chief Complaint:
Diverticulitis
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. Cynthia Nelson is a very pleasant 64 yo WF seen at the request of Dr. Chen for acute sigmoid diverticulitis.  Available records including labs/ imaging reports from an ER visit and subsequent ER visit/ observation admission reviewed:
7/23/2025 - CT Abdo/Pelvis with IV contrast - Small hiatal hernia; stomach not adequately distended for evaluation and oral contrast also not administered; left-sided diverticulosis with an inflamed diverticulum (proximal sigmoid)
7/27/2025 - CT Abdo/Pelvis without contrast - Inflammatory changes along the sigmoid have improved compared to CT done a few days ago (7/23/2025)
7/28/2025 - Labs - CBC normal; potassium 3.4, Chem 8 o/w fine; normal coags; CMP normal a few days prior along with CBC.  Other ER labs included a normal lipase, negative troponin, negative D-Dimer.  Patient also says a CT of her chest was done without concern.
Mrs. Nelson reports being seen at two urgent care clinics for a few days of upper back pain and vague abdominal pain.  None of the upper respiratory symptoms that were documented in the initial ER visit note.  CT scan when she went to the ER due to ongoing symptoms showed acute, uncomplicated proximal sigmoid diverticulitis.  Due to ongoing pain (mainly in her upper back), she returned a few days later and was admitted to the observation unit.  IV antibiotics administered along with muscle relaxants, anti-emetics, acetaminophen.  Discharged on several medications including Augmentin (x 10 days), Prednisone taper (60 mg and off within a week), and hydrocodone.
States improvement but not resolution of the abdominal pain.  Upper back pain persists and also notes fatigue.  Massage helped the upper back pain which is what she tired most recently.  Having constipation because she is unsure what can be eaten.  Also has GERD managed with an OTC PPI and that has worsened with the abdominal pain.
No prior EGD or colonoscopy.  Denies any family h/o GI malignancies.

Assessment:
1. Acute sigmoid diverticulitis (uncomplicated)/ abnormal CT scan - Questions about diverticular disease answered.  No need for repeat labs or a 3rd CT scan.  Normal WBC on all labs reassuring.  Colonoscopy 6-8 weeks after the episode to document resolution and rule out a concurrent colon cancer.  No prior colonoscopy.
2. Change in bowel habits - Prior history of severe constipation on semaglutide which she stopped a few months ago.  The constipation improved but she is now having trouble again.  Resume fiber in her diet and start Miralax.  Fiber supplementation if Miralax causes diarrhea.  Asked to stop the hydrocodone as she has been taking it daily since discharge.
3. GERD - Mild worsening since being diagnosed with diverticulitis.  Advised to adjust when she takes the OTC PPI.
4. Fatigue/ upper back pain - Advised to discuss further with Dr. Chen.  I cannot explain either symptom with the sigmoid diverticulitis.  Referred pain from the colon to her upper back/ lower neck area does not make any sense.
5. Obesity - Long term weight loss advised.
6. Colon cancer screening - No prior colonoscopy.
7. All questions answered.
Plan:
Eat small meal portions
Do not eat 3 hours before laying down.
Miralax titration recommended
Gradual titration of fiber supplementation discussed (Benefiber, psyllium (Metamucil) or Citrucel - 1-2 heaped tablespoons daily with fluids.

He has lost approximately 25 pounds over the last 9 months. He has tried multiple antacids without significant improvement. He is also tried multiple antidiarrheal medications also without improvement. He reports that over the last 2 weeks he has become diaphoretic frequently with nausea. He denies any chest pain or abdominal pain. Symptoms do not worsen with activity. He has had 2 colonoscopies and 2 EGDs in the last 10 years. No biopsies were taken on the last colonoscopy. Assessment:
Mr. Campbell is a 65-year-old male seen for diarrhea, vomiting, nausea. While he has a long history of diarrhea, it appears to have significantly worsened in the last 6 to 9 months and is now occurring with significant, nausea/vomiting as well as weight loss. Differential diagnosis includes microscopic colitis, PNET, functional disorder, Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, or other hormone secreting tumor. If he continues to have diarrhea it may be worth workup for hormone secreting tumors. Will first perform EGD and colonoscopy and stool studies with fecal calprotectin and fecal elastase.

Chief Complaint:
IBS
History of Present Illness:
38 year old female with PMHx of hypothyroidism, PCOS, anxiety and depression who is being seen in consultation for IBS-C and LUQ. She notes a long period of time of feeling poorly and is on a health journey.  She notes cold intolerance, poor sleep and dry skin.  She has been working with her endocrinologist to start thyroid medication but notes no change in her thyroid symptoms.  She also has a long History of constipation and can go a few weeks without a bowel movement. In the last 9 to 12 months it has progressed to up to 4 weeks without a bowel movement. Sometimes she will have normal stools have extreme movement. During these times she will only pass very watery stool. Her stools tend to run from the but are never hard that she will have bad bloating and distention. She has only tried managing her symptoms with increased water intake but has not tried any stool softeners or laxatives. She will occasionally have bright red blood harder stools. She has been treated for hemorrhoids with sclerotherapy earlier year. She also has a slight vaginal prolapse which she went to PT many years ago and seem to get only temprorary benefit. She has continued her home exercises.  For a few months she would have left upper quadrant pain after eating it would be worse if she remains sitting after the meal. She had indigestion and heartburn. This has not occurred in the last few weeks.Of note, she was seen by a naturopath who did a GI map. She tried a GI detox that was not helpful. She then establish care with a nutritionist and she had all of her blood work. Her nutrition wanted us to look at her fecal calprotectin and zolulin levels.
GI Mapp:  fecal cal 394, zolulin 369.2

Diagnoses:

Incomplete passage of stool
Vaginal prolapse
Hypothyroidism
Assessment:
38 year old female with PMHx of hypothyroidism, PCOS, anxiety and depression who is being seen in consultation for IBS-C and LUQ.
Patient has a long history of constipation that has worsened in the last few months. I suspect this is multifactorial due to inadequately treated hypothyroidism, perimenopause and IBS-C. She was advised to complete a bowel cleanout and start magnesium oxide 500mg nightly and titrate up as needed. This may also help with her sleep. She was advised to use squatty potty. Can consider ARM and referral to pelvic PT in the future. May also need to consider a prescribe secretagogue.
Discussed the lack of academic research behind the GI Mapp and limitation of interpretation.  Will repeat fecal calprotectin.
Patient's intermittent rectal bleeding is due to small hemorrhoids seen on anoscopy exam today. We are treating constipation as above. Will proceed with nonurgent colonoscopy. Suflave.
Procedure was explained to patient in detail. Risks and benefits of endoscopic procedures were d/w patient in detail. Risks are but no limited to infection, bleeding, perforation, chance of a missed lesion, drug reaction or rare fatality. Patient was given an opportunity to ask questions regarding the procedure. All questions were answered. The patient agrees with the above plan. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction. This documentation was generated through the use of dictation and/or voice recognition software. Proofing takes place, however unintentional errors in spelling and grammar can occur.
Plan:
Recommended low fat, low cholesterol diet and exercise to achieve ideal body weight.*

Given ongoing symptoms despite high-dose PPI therapy, discussed consideration for EGD and after reviewing the risk, benefits and alternatives patient would like to proceed.  Constipation differential includes medication, thyroid disorder, chronic idiopathic constipation, IBS-C, slow transit constipation, pelvic floor dysfunction. Further diagnostic testing includes laboratory testing, imaging, and endoscopic evaluation. X-ray of the abdomen for further evaluation of stool burden & bowel gas pattern.  Maintain adequate hydration with at least 2L of water per day, bowel regimen as needed with MiraLAX 1-2 times daily and increase dietary fiber and OTC fiber like Benefiber 2-3 times daily but caution on potential for increased gas and/or bloating. Increase exercise as tolerated.  If workup unrevealing and ongoing symptoms despite better control of bowel habits with bowel regimen, may consider colonoscopy especially given no prior records and done >5 years ago.

Chief Complaint:
anemia
History of Present Illness:
28-year-old female referred for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia by Dr. Juvvadi.
This is a 28-year-old female who is referred for evaluation of iron deficiency anemia with concern for possible malabsorption. She was seen by her primary care provider, Kristen Montgomery, PA, for a yearly physical in May, where blood work revealed anemia. She was subsequently referred to hematology with Dr. Juvvadi. Laboratory studies revealed a hemoglobin of 7.4 g/dL, ferritin of 4 ng/mL, and an iron saturation of 2%. Subsequent labs showed a white blood cell count of 5.2 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.8 g/dL, and platelets of 263 K/uL. She reports symptoms of pica, specifically ice craving. She does not feel particularly weak or tired. She completed five rounds of intravenous iron infusions and was advised to take a daily oral iron supplement, which she takes intermittently. She denies any known bleeding, has not seen blood in her stool, and has not had black, tarry stools. Her weight has been stable for years. She is not a vegetarian and has a regular diet. She reports no heavy menstrual bleeding; her menses last one to two days. Her last gynecological visit was in February, and she has regular pelvic exams.
She denies any upper GI symptoms including heartburn, reflux, nausea, vomiting, bloating, or dysphagia. She denies lower GI symptoms such as change in bowel habits, diarrhea, or abdominal pain. She reports regular daily bowel movements. She denies a history of blood in the stool or rectal bleeding. Pertinent negatives include no fever and no significant weight loss.
GI medications: Oral iron supplement, taken every other day.
Her past medical history is not significant. She has no history of gastrointestinal surgeries, including gastric bypass. Menarche was at age 14. She has never received a packed red blood cell transfusion. Her mother has a history of anemia. There is no known family history of sickle cell disease, other hemoglobinopathies, or celiac disease. She is of Western European descent (English, Irish, Scandinavian).
She works in finance. She denies tobacco or illicit drug use. Alcohol use was not discussed.

Diagnoses:
Anemia, iron deficiency (c,e)
Assessment:
Assessment & Plan:
- Iron deficiency anemia
1. Iron deficiency anemia: The etiology of her significant iron deficiency anemia is unclear. Given the lack of heavy menstrual bleeding, a gastrointestinal source of blood loss or malabsorption must be ruled out. While she denies overt signs of bleeding, microscopic blood loss from conditions such as colitis, ulcers, or polyps remains a possibility. Celiac disease is also a consideration given her European ancestry and potential for malabsorption. The plan is to proceed with a comprehensive GI evaluation.
- Plan to proceed with an EGD and colonoscopy to evaluate for a source of gastrointestinal bleeding and to obtain small bowel biopsies to rule out celiac disease.
- Discussed that if the EGD and colonoscopy are unremarkable, we will then consider a video capsule endoscopy to evaluate the small bowel.
- A letter will be sent to Dr. Juvvadi to update her on the plan.
- The patient will be scheduled for the procedures by our office staff. She was given the option of having the procedure at the hospital or an ambulatory surgery center and was counseled that the surgery center is often more cost-effective.
- The bowel preparation options, including a liquid preparation and tablets, were discussed. The patient has elected to use the liquid preparation.
After Visit Summary:
- Your visit today was for iron deficiency anemia, which means your body is low on iron. The cause is not clear.
- We discussed that even though you are not seeing any bleeding, it is important to check your gastrointestinal tract (stomach and colon) for hidden sources of blood loss or for conditions that might prevent you from absorbing iron properly, like celiac disease.
- We have planned for you to have an EGD (upper endoscopy) and a colonoscopy. This involves using cameras to look at your esophagus, stomach, and colon. We will also take small tissue samples (biopsies) to test for celiac disease.
- Our office will contact you to schedule these procedures.
- You will need to take a special bowel preparation medication before the colonoscopy to clean out your colon. We discussed the options, and you chose the liquid preparation. You will receive detailed instructions for this.
- You will need to arrange for an adult to drive you to and from the procedure, as you will receive sedation.
Plan:
EGD/Colonoscopy with Anesthesia Provider/CRNA who is hereby directed and authorized to administer anesthesia - 43235/45378
Clenpiq 10 mg-3.5 gram- 12 gram/175 mL Drink 2 bottle by mouth split dose as directed
Additional Notes:
Additional Recommendations/Instructions:
1. Today we discussed your upcoming procedure:
- We discussed the importance of an excellent preparation to minimize the risk of missed polyps. **Please read the instructions for the preparation one week prior to your exam.**
- Risks include sedation related risks, perforation, immediate or delayed bleeding, infection, as well as the low risk of incomplete procedure due to retained food, poor preparation, anatomy, or a large/difficult polyp, requiring a repeat. Please call if you are having pain or bleeding after a procedure.
- If you take aspirin, you may continue taking this. Please avoid all tobacco products on the day of your procedure.
- If we remove polyps or take biopsies, you can expect to hear those results in about 1-2 weeks via either letter, phone call, or portal message. Please call 972-637-8480 if you do not hear within 3 weeks.
